Title: Smart Surat struggling to breathe easy
Body:
Surat: Toxic fumes released by the high number of vehicles everyday, coupled with the smoke from dyeing and printing units, is turning the air around Surat city's commercial areas unbreathable. The city, mainly those parts under industrial segments, are forced to survive in an atmosphere polluted with suspended particulate matter (PM) 2.5 mm and PM 10 mm, said GPCB officials.With a population count of more than 50 lakh, Surat city - the eighth-most populated city of the country at present - has 31 lakh vehicles of all sizes and 5,000 km roads. With Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) continuously monitoring the levels of air pollution at 10 different spots round the year, the city has fallen from its earlier 'good' position owing to the dip in its air quality to 'moderately polluted' category according to National Air Quality Index (AQI) . Experts fear that if the pollution continues to grow at this rate it will take less than 3 years for the city to reach 'poor' to 'very poor' levels as per AQI standards. 
Surat's phenomenal rise in vehicular population - addition of 1.5 million vehicles in a decade - is the root cause of deterioration in air quality. Recently, the World Bank officials too expressed their fears on the rising pollution levels, especially PM10mg |M3 and PM2.5 mg|M3, in the city. Dr Namrata Jariwala, an expert in pollution and environment issues from Sardar Vallbhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT), however, does not blame vehicles alone for the pollution. "Apart from increase in number of vehicles, there is also the emissions from industrial units for the fuel type they use," she said. When compared to highly polluted cities like Delhi, Surat too has high pollution levels that is visible from a filter paper turning black in two hours even at spots like Piplod, she explained. "However, what helps Surat still breathe easy is its climatic conditions. In winter such pollutants can cause eye irritation or running nose or throat infection but apart from local irritants, we do not feel higher impact of pollution. Compared to hot places like Delhi, we live in 10-15 degree Celsius which helps pollutants to disperse easily," she said.Parag Dave, regional officer at GPCB, Surat, said, "Ongoing construction activity, demolition work sites, bigger project sites, vehicle emissions are some of the things that increase pollutants in air along with hydrocarbon emissions due to different types of machines. We need to control such construction activities along with number of vehicles plying in residential areas of the city."

Title: SMC plans to borrow Rs1,925 crore from World Bank
Body:
Surat: The standing committee of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has approved a proposal to procure loan of Rs1,925 crore from World Bank. The money will be used on pollution-free development projects and also to conduct a study along with Gujarat Engineering Research Institute (GERI) and Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) on pollution in the city.Jawalant Naik, environment engineer, SMC, told TOI, "SMC will need money from a financial body like World Bank to undertake a number of development projects in 2019-21. The standing committee has approved the proposal and hence we will beginning the loan procurement process soon. We have identified projects in different segments in which SMC's contribution will be around 20 per cent maximum. 
The civic body will receive subsidies to the tune of 25 per cent from the state government." A team from World Bank had evinced interest in teaming up with SMC in undertaking a number of environmental friendly projects. The civic body will be undertaking construction of roads, bridges, traffic islands, gardens, sewage and solid waste disposal projects in the next few years. Meanwhile, a separate proposal on measuring air quality in the city was also approved by the standing committee. A SMC team along with Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) and Gujarat Engineering Research Institute (GERI) will measure air quality in different parts of the city. The study will find out causes for pollution and recommend measures to tackle it.12 AIR QUALITY MONITORING MACHINES TO BE INSTALLEDThe civic body plans to install another 15 air pollution monitoring machines in the city soon after Lok Sabha elections. Two machines are already functioning at Varachha and Limbayat areas. A SMC officer said, "We are waiting for National Green Tribunal's (NGT) guidelines. It will stipulate air quality monitoring machines according to a city's size." SMC officials had earlier planned to have at least two machines in all the eight municipal zones of the city. The cost of one air pollution monitoring machine is approximately Rs50 lakh.

Title: North Indians more prone to stroke owing to diet, says study
Body:
CHANDIGARH: A study under Indo-US collaborative stroke project has revealed that people living in the northern part of India receive more severe strokes compared to the population in the southern part of the country. This vulnerability is mainly due to plaque in atherosclerosis - the larger artery - and factors like diet, vitamin D levels, genetic risks, seasonal variations, and air pollution. The study has been recently published in 'International journal of stroke'. The study was conducted in association with a US-based coordinating center at five academic centres in India, including All-India Institutes of Medical Sciences in New Delhi (182 candidates); Christian Medical College and Hospital in Ludhiana (574 candidates); PGI in Chandigarh (306 candidates); Nizam's Institute of Medical Sciences in Hyderabad (443 candidates) and Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology in Thiruvananthapuram (561 candidates). A total of 2,066 stroke patients (1,060 from north India and 1,006 from the south) were diagnosed. 
"In the study, we examined different risk factors in people belonging to northern and southern parts of India. This has enabled treatment and prevention according to the risk factors," said Professor Dheeraj Khurana, a neurologist at the PGI, who conducted this study.The study also revealed that most the patients in the north, who had acute stroke, reached hospital either by their own vehicle or a private transportation. Among the patients, who received intravenous thrombolysis IVT and/or intra-arterial treatment, 60.2% patients had used a private transportation and 30.6% patients were transferred from other hospitals.In the South, 62.2% patients were transferred from other hospitals and 25% arrived using a private transportation. The centers in the south have better coordination with local hospitals when it comes to transporting patients to comprehensive stroke centres, the study revealed."Due to high patient load and fewer in-patient bed availability, many minor strokes and non-acute stroke patients do not get admission in centres in the north," said Prof Khurana.

Title: UT demands progress report on CTU projects
Body:
CHANDIGARH: The UT administration has sought progress report on Chandigarh Transport Undertaking (CTU) projects, including purchase of electric buses.A senior UT official said after getting the progress report from CTU, the administration will accordingly send the final report to Centre.Recently, the Centre denied to release funds for UT's project of electric buses and thereafter the administration had decided to purchase the buses on its own. The UT administration has now also floated tenders in this regard. Earlier, the administration had written a letter to the Union ministry of heavy industries and public enterprises for the funding of the project, but the ministry denied to release the budget.According to information, the UT had planned to buy 20 electric buses for local routes to fight air pollution. 
There was budgetary estimate of Rs 32 crore for the project.The cost of each electric bus is between Rs 1.25 crore to Rs 1.40 crore, which were planned to be bought under a central government scheme, in which 60% of the cost will be borne by the Union ministry of heavy industries and public enterprises.UT administrator VP Singh Badnore had approved the project in November 2016 and thereafter the CTU had started the process of introducing electric buses in the city under the Smart City plan. The CTU had planned to induct electric buses in its fleet with an aim to cut down on pollution level. Over the years, the quality of air in the city has deteriorated beyond permissible level. Data compiled by the Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) points out that the level of repairable suspended particulate matter (RSPM) has been recorded above the permissible limits, that is, 100 microgram per cubic metre (mcg/cu m).In August 2017, the UT administration had even trialled buses from various companies. During the trial, weight of around 1,750kg was put in the buses. An 11-member team was constituted for inspection and compiling a report. Based on the report of the team, the authorities took the decision to purchase battery-operated buses.According to officials, the battery-operated buses have a life of 10 years and cover over 250km in one charge. It takes around six hours to charge the bus.

Title: 1,686 mango farmers seek compensation for poor yield
Body:
Surat: The luscious Valsadi Hafoos (alphonso) has fallen prey to severe industrial pollution in the mango belt of south Gujarat, which is also the hub of chemical industries.For the first time in so many years, farmers of Valsad district have demanded compensation from the government for the failure of mango crop. In a memorandum submitted to the district collector recently, 1,686 farmers stated that besides inclement weather conditions, the biggest contributor to the crop failure was air pollution. As a result of the foul air, the mango flowers have turned black, they said.Farmers in the mango stretch from from Chikhli in Navsari to Vapi in Valsad district have also asked the government to carry out detailed investigation to find out the causes of production losses, which they claimed was anything between 50-80%.They also requested Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) to install air pollution monitoring system in each village."Flowers in top half portion of the tree turned black while in the remaining half, flowering was normal. 
In such cases the production falls to half. The situation has only aggravated in the last three years, and the production has fallen to three tonnes only from 22 tonnes in my orchard of 3,000 mango trees," said Vinod Patel, sarpanch of Gorgam village in Valsad.N U Patel, deputy director, horticulture, Valsad, "A number of farmers have suffered heavy mango crop loss and the yield has gone down drastically. Air pollution caused by the industries in the vicinity of these farms cannot be ruled out as the reason for this crop failure."Valsadi Hafoos grown in south Gujarat are exported as well and this mango variety is known for its distinctive sweet taste. "Out of the 4,000 mango tree in my orchard, I have uprooted 400 and replaced these with sugarcane. This year too, I pruned 100 trees due to crop failure. The production has dropped 80 percent in last three years and we are not even able to meet the production cost of pesticide, fertiliser and other expenses," said Kantilal Patel, a farmer from Tighra. "There is no other reason but pollution and we are suffering heavy loss of production," he said.The farmers are demanding Rs 18,000 compensation per hectare to recover the cost of pesticide and fertilisers. Patel said, "Excessive use of pesticide can also lead to production loss, but this is yet to be investigated." Major chemical industries are concentrated in Vapi, Umargam and Sarigam Industrial pollution has remained major cause of concern for locals in this belt where punitive actions have also been taken by the government against the polluters. In some cases locals have resorted to protest while fighting against pollution."The mango production is dropping due to sudden fluctuation in temperature in the last two years. The fluctuation is result of global warming and climate change for which pollution is one of the causes. However, there is no specific study of effect of pollution on mango cultivation," said B M Patel, principal, Aspee College of Horticulture, Navsari Agriculture University (NAU).

Title: Their answer to bad air: Shift ministries out of city
Body:
New Delhi: Azad Bharatam, a new "liberal" political party, has called for shifting of Union government ministries, departments and constitutional authorities out of Delhi and relocating these to other states and Union Territories to reduce the capital's population by 30-35 lakh and bring air pollution and congestion within tolerable limits.Elaborating on the plea, the party's founder, Rakesh Agarwal, said a Delhiite died 10 years sooner due to air pollution, which also caused 30,000 deaths per annum - 20 times more than road fatalities."Delhi is the most polluted capital city in the world. It is a global shame and air pollution should be declared a national emergency just like UK's Parliament did on May 1," he said.The party, however, feels that an exemption could be made for Parliament, Rashtrapati Bhavan, PMO, ministry of external affairs and the constitutional bench of Supreme Court. "Can anything be more important than life itself?
 The day is not far when every school-going child wears a mask attached to an oxygen tank. Showing commitment to environment and transport in election manifestoes is not enough; the political parties must frame and lay bare their plans to tackle the epidemic of air pollution and traffic jams," Agarwal, an RTI activist working with auto rickshaw drivers and a former AAP member, said.According to Rajiv Sharma, another party leader, they are looking for more experts to find out plausible solutions to Delhi's problems."We have just started. We want to change governance. We will register 4-5 months later and contest the 2020 assembly elections. There are 8-10 different issues we will talk about. In a week or so, we will talk about how full statehood for Delhi can help people and ward off sealing drives," Sharma said.He added that they planned to bring serious governance into sharp focus while making negative politics irrelevant.

Title: City's air quality index hides real-time data: Experts
Body:
Chennai: The state's air quality index released by Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board on Tuesday conceals more than it reveals, according to environmentalists who have termed flawed the way data was presented by calculating averages.Shweta Narayan, coordinator of Healthy Energy Initiative India, said toxins such as PM 2.5 (particulate matter with a diameter less 2.5 micrometres) had significant effects on health and readings that were derived by calculating averages could not be relied on. Ideally, PM 2.5 should be below 40. "We need to have more data sets. Only 24-hour monitoring of air will be able to provide data to draw any conclusion about pollution levels in the city," she said.The data did not reveal any information about the number of days the monitoring was done. 
It `was based on an average, which was a flawed approach, she said.Similarly, the number of samples and the average they had taken were also not clear. The PCB authorities had done an average of averages and claimed only a few hotspots in the state were polluted.Surprisingly, in North Chennai, there was no data from the Ennore region, which had a thermal power station. This station emits fly ash, which is collected in a pond in the Ennore creek. "This fly ash is a major contributor of pollution in the city," she said.Finding a place in the NCAP will force the cities to come up with reduction and mitigation measures on air pollution. Currently, there is no such provisions to reduce pollution in Chennai, Madurai and Trichy, she pointed out.Former environment engineer D Velazhagan said PM 10 levels were increasing in many residential areas, including Adyar. Compared to last year, PM 10 levels had considerably gone up. All areas in the city have exceeded their limits in PM 2.5 value, he said.

Title: 'Breathing in clean air can up life expectancy'
Body:
PATNA: A short lifespan, respiratory illnesses, cardiovascular diseases and psychological ill-effects are some serious health hazards, which people can experience, due to prolonged exposure to bad air quality, claim doctors. Health experts urge Patnaites to take precautions not just outside, but in their houses as well to avoid air-borne health problems."Air pollution can be ambient or household. 
While the former occurs due to emission of smoke from vehicles and industries, the latter can be caused due to the use of air fresheners and house paints. Ambient air pollution is responsible for bronchitis, emphysema and lung cancer, whereas household pollution can cause cough, asthma and skin irritation," said city-based pulmonologist Dr Sanjay Kumar.Physician Dr Pratyush Kumar claimed that the average life expectancy would increase by 1.7 years if the air quality improved. "People with tuberculosis should stay away from industrial areas as continuous exposure to unhealthy air can aggravate their disease," he said.Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences' (IGIMS) skin department associate professor Dr Kranti advised people to wear masks while going outside and eat protein-rich food. He explained, "Proper diet and precautions can reduce the ill-effects of air pollution."Some health-conscious Patnaites are trying their best to protect themselves from the hazards of pollution. Pataliputra Colony resident Samreen Faridi said, "I always cover my face while leaving my house."Another resident of the same colony, Kumari Ria prefers walking to using her scooter. She pointed out, "Walking keeps me fit. Besides, there is no vehicular emission."

Title: Women too vulnerable to lung cancer: Docs
Body:
Madurai: The notion that lung cancer occurs predominantly among men does not hold true as a notable percentage of women too suffer from the disease, say doctors here. However, they also add that the survival rate of people with lung cancer is significantly high if treated at a very early stage.The doctors were speaking at Vadamalayan Hospitals where three procedures were performed on as many patients - two of whom were women - with lung cancer in the last one month alone. Consultant surgical oncologist at the hospital Dr S Alagu Ganesh said there was a general conception that only smoking could increase the risk of lung cancer, which was not the case. 
"Since only smoking is perceived by the general public to be the only reason for lung cancer, they think only men are at higher risk," he said. Dr Ganesh added that though the exact cause for lung cancer among women could not be determined in many cases, the possible reasons could be air pollution caused by firewood stove, industrial pollution, genetic mutation and even hereditary. The doctors also said that at Vadamayalan Hospitals, about 30% to 40% of patients with lung cancer constituted women.The experts said that while the overall five-year survival rate was about 18%, if detected and treated early, it could go up by 60% to 70%. "When an elderly person repeatedly coughs, it is often considered to be only due to old age. But if it's recurring, then they should be checked sooner," chief cardiothoracic surgeon Dr P Babu said. The three who underwent lung resections at the hospital last month included a 34-year-old woman with carcinoma in the left lung, 70-year-old man with right lower lobectomy and a 74-year-old woman with left lower lobectomy. The doctors said the surgeries were successful and they were able to send the patients home. The doctors also said that every year 1.61 million new cases of lung cancer were reported out of which 1.38million died, making lung cancer the leading cause of cancer-related mortality.

Title: Over one crore saplings to be planted this monsoon
Body: Visakhapatnam: In keeping with this year's theme for World Environment Day- air pollution, the forest department is emphasising on tree plantation. There are many species of trees that absorb dust that help minimise the impact of air pollution.According to reports, over one crore saplings will be planted in the district this year, in the monsoon. Divisional forest officer (DFO), C Selvan said, "The saplings are being raised in various nurseries and would be planted across the district during the monsoon. Our target is to plant one crore saplings. We will also distribute saplings to farmers, especially cashew, casuarina and eucalyptus saplings. Various public sector units, corporations, educational and health institutions have been roped in for the drive."The DFO further said there are various kinds of trees such as pongamia, neem, ficus, jamun and badam that help reduce pollution by absorbing dust. These trees provide shade and enhance green cover, helping release more oxygen into the atmosphere. "We are choosing species which can check air pollution," the DFO said."Our plantation drive will not be confined to the city, but will include rural and agency areas too," the DFO added.

Title: Pollution fears rise over proposed Bainguinim plant
Body:
Panaji: Residents of Bainguinim and Old Goa on Saturday demanded that the state government shift the proposed 250-tonne garbage treatment plant away from Bainguinim. They claimed that if the plant was set up there, leachate would contaminate the groundwater and surrounding fields.Citizens, under the banner of Pornem Goemcho Nagrik Monch, claimed that once the plant was operational, air and water pollution would affect the 4,000-odd people living in the area. All the housing projects along the nearby Kadamba plateau rely on borewells for their domestic water supply, which is the main reason why the residents have vowed to oppose the facility."We will have to approach NGT and courts to stop the garbage plant from being set up there," the organisation's president, Ambar Amonkar, told reporters.NIO scientist Dr Anil Kumar Saran, who was also present, said there were "certain gaps in the study" conducted as part of the environment impact assessment (EIA). "I am not saying the waste treatment plant should not come up, but a lot more research should be done," he said. 
Former head of Goa University's microbiology department, Joe D'Souza, also said that a proper ground study needed to be done before the government went ahead with the project.Saran suggested instead of a rapid EIA, the Goa Waste Management Corporation should conduct a year-long study to identify the flora and fauna around the heritage site. "The garbage plant is based on a bio-methanation process, which means methane will be released. Methane is bad for the environment, especially for lakes and ponds," he said.Land for the proposed Bainguinim garbage treatment plant was identified in 2008 as part of the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission, while residential complexes came up around the area from 2011 onwards. The residents, however, refused to blame the builders for constructing the complexes within 500 metres of the proposed garbage facility.

Title: Drop in air quality could stoke breathing issues: Doctors
Body:
Edited. 270 words. To go with 'Let Our City Breathe' logo.Times News NetworkPanaji: Falling air quality levels in some parts of the state could make people living in those areas vulnerable to respiratory diseases. 
Doctors say people with pre-existing breathing conditions, such as asthma, are particularly susceptible.In its report for 2018-19 the Goa State Pollution Control Board (GSPCB) has singled out the state capital and three major towns  Mapusa, Vasco and Mormugao (MPT)  for dwindling air quality. It has found respirable particulate matter (PM) to be beyond the permissible limit in all four areas that together accommodate a population of over three lakh."If a person is already suffering from a respiratory problem like bronchitis, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, air pollution could aggravate it. Poor air quality could also cause an allergy-like breathing condition," city-based doctor Rufino Monteiro, says. The annual limit for levels of PM10 (particulate matter that is 10 microns or less in diameter) is 60 microgram/m3. Mormugao (MPT), however, registered a PM10 count of 117 microgram/m3 between April 2018 and March 2019. Vasco recorded the second-highest level of 87, followed by Panaji with 83 and Mapusa with 67. A source appropriation study is under way in Vasco in view of coal pollution there. It is aimed at quantifying the contribution of emissions from various sources that contribute to air pollution.Prepared as part of the National Air Monitoring Programme, the GSPCB's report for 2018-19 has also found PM2.5 to be moderately high in Panaji, Vasco and Mormugao (MPT). It attributes the cause to vehicular movement, construction activities and industrial emission. "Data indicates that levels of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide are within permissible limits," it adds.

Title: Eco concerns over plan to link Balbharati, Paud Road
Body:
Pune: The proposed link road between Balbharati on Senapati Bapat Road and Paud Phata have drawn environmental concerns at a stakeholders' meeting on Saturday.Citizens and activists said the project should not impact the area's biodiversity, even as a solution was needed to decongest the choked Law College Road. The road was proposed to free up Law College Road by providing an alternative to motorists travelling from Kothrud to Senapati Bapat Road and beyond. The project was challenged in the Bombay high court, which directed a detailed environmental and traffic impact study. 
Saturday's meeting, held by PMC-appointed consulting firm VK:e environmental, was a bid to get feedback from the stakeholders.The study deals with existing environment quality, land use, hydrogeology, air, water and soil quality, along the proposed alignment of the road.As per the plan, 800m of forest land, 200m of reserved park, 500m of residential/slum areas and 600m of public-semi public zones will be used for the road."We have taken up an extensive study to identify both the positive and negative environmental and social effects of the project. We will develop an action plan to enhance the positives and mitigate the negatives to ensure long-term sustainability," Anagha Paranjape-Purohit of VK:e environmental said.Paranjape-Purohit said citizens' suggestions will be included in the final draft, which will be submitted to the civic administration.Citizens, however, were not entirely convinced about the project. "It will be just a short-term solution for a tiny section of the city. The entire city suffers from traffic congestion and pollution and needs a holistic solution," Sushma Date, a local resident, said. "It is ironic that a road that will destroy an urban forest is proposed as a solution to high pollution levels," Date said, adding, "Instead of more roads, the PMC should improve public transport."Elected representatives backed the project. "The road will help resolve traffic issues in the area. Residents and pedestrians suffer from daily traffic jams and there has been a significant increase in air pollution in the Law College Road and Karve Road areas," corporator Madhuri Sahastrabuddhe said. Manjushree Khardekar, another corporator, said steps can be taken to mitigate the environmental impact. Do you use the Law College Road for your daily commute? Do you have suggestions that could make this stretch safer and more motorist-friendly? Send your letters to TOIPune@timesgroup.com

Title: Korean activist helps diagnose city pollution
Body: Visakhapatnam: Noted Korean environmental activist KH Choi and city-based activist Bolisetti Satyanarayana visited several sewage treatment plants (STPs) in Vizag city and some industries in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram districts in the last three days. Speaking to the media here in Visakhapatnam on Saturday, Satyanarayana said that they visited STPs, including the 13MLD plant in Mudasarlova, 25MLD plant in Appughar and 38MLD plant near Lakshmi Talkies. "Mitigation of all types of pollutions, including soil, air and water, is the urgent need to save life on earth. As part of this mission, I have travelled to Korea recently to understand how the Koreans are able to address this menace," he said.Choi added, "The industries can make money from the pollution as they can recover heat from the stack and use it in their process which can reduce their power usage/ fuel consumption. And most importantly, this would reduce air pollution in the air."

Title: Demolition: IIT-Madras warns of serious environmental impact
Body:
Thiruvananthapuram: Demolition of apartment complexes at Maradu would generate waste at a rate of 450kg/sq m and for a building with a built-up area of 1,00,000 sq ft, the demolition waste generated would be about 4500 tonnes. It would trigger pollution impact of various kinds within a radius of 1km, said an environment impact assessment (EIA) study by IIT-Madras.It would require 0.25 acres to pile up the debris resulting from demolition of building (1,00,000 sq ft in area) and the debris would take up a layer measuring (approx) 3m high. The team cited implosion by explosives as the most-appropriate method but added that it would be impossible to remove the foundations, especially the 35m deep cast-in-situ bored reinforced concrete piles expected under the buildings.The final study report, which was submitted to state government late on Tuesday, warned of significant environmental impact like air and noise pollution that could cover a radius of 1km and vibrations that could damage nearby buildings and disturb their occupants. 
It said that proper restoration is a must if demolition is carried out and it must be done based on the 'polluter pays' principle.The study was done by an eight-member team led by Dr Ravindra Gettu, dean, Industrial Consultancy and Sponsored Research, IIT-Madras. Site inspections were done by the team on July 3, 2019 and on July 27, 2019. The team held discussions with KCZMA, KSCSTE and Maradu municipality officials before preparing the report."Though air pollution is short-lived, resuspension of particulate matter at a later time, due to favourable atmospheric conditions, is a cause for concern. People living in nearby apartments, waterways and vulnerable plants would be at grave risk due to air pollution. The noise generated will be very high (of the order 130dB in case of implosion method). The noise will be heard a kilometre away. Even at a distance of 250m, the noise level will be 80dB, which is more than the permissible limit," the report said.The report also took note of carbon footprint and said that demolition of highrises before the end of their service lives (such as the ones in Maradu) would lead to a significant negative impact, arising from loss or waste of carbon footprint and embodied energy."If you consider an apartment with 1,500 sq ft carpet area in a reinforced concrete building, the wasted carbon footprint is at least 100 tonnes of carbon dioxide. It could then be estimated that the demolition of a complex with 80 such apartments, with a remaining life of 50 years, would have the same negative impact as the removal of 1 sq km of mangroves, over the same period of time," it said.The team also studied the present environmental impact of apartment complexes. During inspections, it was observed that sewage from several complexes is discharged into the nearby backwaters directly without treatment or after only partial treatment, which could lead to severe pollution.

Title: Transport Corporation to roll out eco-friendly buses
Body:
PATNA: The Bihar State Road Transport Corporation (BSRTC) is set to roll out eco-friendly buses in the city. It will soon procure four electric buses and convert the diesel engines of 20 existing buses to compressed natural gas (CNG).According to a BSRTC official, the bidding process for purchasing the electric buses and converting diesel engines to CNG has been initiated. "Depending on how the trial goes, we may install CNG kits in more buses," the official told TOI.The BSRTC runs at least 110 diesel-based buses in Patna under the city bus service.The supply of CNG in the state capital began after Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated the Patna City Gas Distribution Network at Begusarai on February 17 this year. 
At present, the gas is being supplied to two petrol pumps at Rukanpura and Bypass road.The BSRTC official said, "We are planning to run the electric buses on Bailey Road as it is wide. Such buses can cover a distance up to 150km after being recharged."Transport department officials claimed that efforts to run eco-friendly electric buses were being made in order to curb air pollution. As per recent surveys, Patna is among the most polluted cities in the world and vehicular emission is one of the reasons behind it.The Bihar State Pollution Control Board had released an action plan for controlling air pollution in Patna on May 10 last year. It envisaged use of cleaner fuels like CNG in the state capital.Environmental experts hailed the move of the transport department to introduce CNG and electric buses. "Vehicular emission leads to air pollution and the scenario worsens in the peak winter months of December and January. Hence, introducing eco-friendly vehicles is a welcome step," Central University of South Bihar's environmental science department professor Pradhan Parth Sarthi said.

Title: Bengaluru: Despite demand, CBD lacks CNG filling station
Body:
BENGALURU: With the entry of Compressed Natural Gas-run quadricycles, drivers are slowly switching to environment-friendly vehicles. But there's a hitch: lack of CNG-filling stations in the heart of the city.Bengaluru is home to 1,257 CNG vehicles and more are expected to hit the roads in the coming days. But the dearth of filling stations in central business district (CBD) is hampering transition to the cleaner fuel.GAIL Gas, a CNG provider, is finding it difficult to procure land for a filling station in CBD. 
At present, Bengaluru has 15 CNG filling stations, of which a majority are on the outskirts. Of the 1,257 CNG vehicles, including cars, taxis, buses, trucks and autorickshaws plying in Bengaluru, 715 are registered in Karnataka.App-based aggregator Uber along with Bajaj Auto recently launched Quadricycle under the UberXS platform. The four-wheeler which is smaller and lighter than a passenger car can accommodate driver plus three others and has become a hit.Srikanth S, who runs a quadricycle says: "It's more economical than an LPG auto but finding a filling station is very difficult. We need stations in the city's core areas." Several LPG auto drivers are also shifting to CNG vehicles.Sources in GAIL Gas said shortage of land in CBD is delaying stations. "We are in talks with major oil marketing firms, including IOCL, to set up CNG stations at their retail outlets," said a source.The existing retail price of CNG is approximately Rs 58.6 per kg. A CNG auto can save about Rs 5,500 per month compared to the LPG version while a CNG taxi can save about Rs 8,000 compared to the diesel model. A CNG car can reduce fuel bill by 40% as opposed to a petrol car, said a GAIL Gas spokesperson."Vehicle emissions are the biggest contributor to air pollution in Bengaluru. CNG is not only environment-friendly but also economical. We have commissioned 23 CNG stations, of which15 are operational. We are planning to set up 100 CNG stations at a cost of Rs 300 crore in next 2-3 years in Bengaluru," said the spokesperson.The city got its first CNG station in October 2016. With commissioning of more stations, it's expected to join the league of cities such as Delhi, Mumbai, Pune, Hyderabad, Indore and Agra. Vehicles can be retrofitted with CNG at four authorised centres (see box). Conversion cost for four-wheelers is around Rs 28,000, two-wheelers Rs 24,000 and autorickshaws Rs 25,000.GAIL gas CNG stationsBeggar's Colony in Prem Nagar, APC Circle in Jigani, near Aero Space Park near Huvinayakanahalli, Srigandadakaval near Magadi Main Road, Bommasandra Industrial Area, Tatanagar near Kodigehalli, Dasanapura near Magadi Road, Peenya Industrial Area, Agara on Sarjapur Road, Doddakannelli (Sarjapur Road), Haldenahali village in Anekal taluk, Sanjeevanagar on Bannerghatta Road, Honnenahalli village near Rajankunte, Virupakshapura near Vidyaranyapura and Hunasamaranahalli village near Jalahobli.Retro fitment centresKanakanagar near RT Nagar, Munishwara Block near Laggere, RMV 2nd Stage, Inner Ring Road near Koramangala.

Title: In a week, city's air quality worsens by 100%
Body:
Chandigarh: The air you are breathing has deteriorated drastically over the last week in the city. From an average air quality index (AQI) of 55 on October 1, the AQI has plunged to 101 on Tuesday - an increase of around 100% - on a day when effigies of Ravana, Meghnad and Kumbhkarna were burnt at 40 locations. However, the air quality remained 'satisfactory' to 'moderate' during the evening hours between 4 pm and 8 pm on Dussehra - a fact that could be misleading. Experts explained the data does not indicate the air quality on Dusshera as the Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) has installed only one Continuous Ambient Air Quality Monitoring Station (CAAQMS) at Panjab University, Sector 25, which gives real time monitoring data. 
The real picture would be clear on Wednesday, when the CPCC would collect data from five different locations.A scientist with the CPCC said Sector 25 machine collects data from in and around Sector 25 and Panjab University. Moreover, wind direction also plays a major role in capturing the data, he said.Recently, the UT administration decided to conduct a source appointment study to help it prepare data to quantify proportion of various elements to the overall level of air pollution. At present, the UT does not have any data to quantify proportion of various elements to the overall level of pollution.Last year, the administration rejected the proposal because of its high cost. In 2017, the environment department representatives held a meeting with officials of Union environment ministry in which it was discussed that IIT, Kanpur, had procured Switzerland-made monitoring devices worth Rs 5 crore each to conduct the study in four different cities. One such device was proposed to be installed in Chandigarh. Debendra Dalai, director, environment, and vice-chairman, CPCC, said as the cost was very high, the proposal was then turned down. Now, they would float a tender to carry out the study, he added.The administration had recently submitted its action plan to control air pollution in Chandigarh to the Union government. The UT had submitted that it has already launched extensive drive against polluting vehicles and prepared an action plan to widen roads and improvement of infrastructure for decongestion of roads.The other initiatives mentioned included synchronization of traffic signals in the city, greening of open areas, and introducing water fountain at major traffic intersections, wherever feasible, with the use of tertiary treated water, promoting battery operated vehicles, green buffers along traffic corridors, and introducing intelligent traffic management system.The UT submitted that the ambient air quality of the city is mainly affected by the increase in the number of vehicles. "There has been an increase of around 60% in the number of vehicles in 10 years with no change in the length of roads. Increase of light motor vehicles (LMVs), basically cars, by more than 100% in the past 10 years in comparison to approximately 48% increase in two-wheelers. This has resulted in more congestion, ultimately contributing to air pollution," the UT had submitted.The officials maintained that dust, crop harvesting seasons, effects of pollens due to greenery, temperature effect, industrial surroundings and vehicular density are the main reasons behind high pollution.TRACKING AQITime | Oct 1 | Oct 84 pm 55 | 1025 pm 57 | 1016 pm 57 | 1007 pm 58 | 998 pm 59 | 989 pm ...| 57AQI: Air Quality Index Six categoriesThe air quality index (AQI) has six categories--good, satisfactory, moderately polluted, poor, very poor, and severeAQI | Remarks |Health impacts0-50 Good | Minimal | Impact51-100 | Satisfactory | Minor breathing discomfort to sensitive people101-200 | Moderate | Breathing discomfort to people with lungs, asthma and heart diseases201-300 | Poor | Breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure301-400 Very poor | Respiratory illness on prolonged exposure401-500 | Severe | Affects healthy people and seriously impacts those with existing diseasesKey pollution factorsDustStubble burningVehicular populationPetroleum productsIndustrial activitiesEffects of pollensMonitoring data from 5 locationsChandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) measures the level of pollution by installing air quality monitoring devices at five locations - Punjab Engineering College Sector 12; Imtech, Sector 39; Industrial Area; Kaimbwala village and Sector 17 - covering institutional area, industrial zone, rural area and commercial areas, respectively. The report from these locations comes after 24 hours as UT follows manual collection of data from these five locations.

Title: Stay healthy and go easy on sweets during festive season
Body:
The environment is so positive as the festive season has begun and the excitement sees no bounds.. navratri and now Diwali. Diwali in our country is celebrated even before it is supposed to be as outings, guests visit, dinner parties, etc.. happen which are inevitable. With this, most often we end up indulging in sweets and other sinful foods, and then of course the guilt which then forces us to try for some easy ways to get rid of those extra kilos. But, the worst part is we want to do all the wrong means to shed that extra fat which again leads to a YO-YO effect.I, therefore would love to share a few health tips with you which would help you stay away from this vicious cycle of: binging, feeling guilty, weight gain, wrong methods of losing weight, weight gain, feeling guilty again.Do try this-1. If you plan to go out, don't go on an empty stomach. 
Eat a small snack before you head out. Choose snacks like boiled corn, mix veggie salad, a fruit bowl, sprouts, veggie soup, yogurt with crushed nuts, whole wheat bread sandwich, etc. This will keep you full and thereby prevent binging/over eating when you are2. If one meal goes for a toss, make sure the rest of the meals are absolutely on track. E.g. If you have a dinner party planned, make sure your meals through the day (breakfast, lunch, snacking items) are very much balanced and healthier.3. Sip water frequently throughout the day. It will keep you hydrated and will also satiate the false hunger.4. Pick healthier desserts- Choose dry fruits/fruits/kheer/phirni/shrikhand (you can make it using hung curd)/dark chocolates/til or peanut chikkis/dink laddoos (gum arabic)/ sheera/ date rolls/ date-walnut mithai, etc. over any other sugar loaded sweets. Sweets made out of jaggery or organic honey are good to go. Remember, we need to take care of the portions too.5. Please choose baked food items over deep fried ones.6. Compensate- It's true that saying "NO" when you are offered sweets by your loved ones especially during this festive season is going to be difficult. Don't worry! Pick one, eat it mindfully and enjoy the eating experience. Now you know what to do next. Compensate for your extra caloric intake in your following meals. More fiber (salads, veggies), good amount of proteins and lesser carbs.7. Go easy on alcohol. It's a major dehydrator and contains empty calories. Choose red wine or vodka over any other hard drinks. Sangria would be the best option here (cut fruits in red wine).8. Be a health-conscious host this Diwali. Serve snacks like dhokla, masalapeanuts, unsalted nuts and dry fruits, sprout-chaat, fruit salad, idlis, baked chaklis Avoid serving soft drinks or artificial juices. Lemon water, jal jeera, flavoured milk, spiced buttermilk, fresh fruit juice would be some better options here.9. Fire crackers are going to pollute the air. The pollutants (free radicals) have an easy access into our body as we breathe. Neutralize the free radicals by consuming adequate antioxidants through colourful fruits, berries and vegetables.10. Last but not the least, don't forget to work out! Workouts would kick your body metabolism in high gear, helping you burn calories faster. It's best to get your workout done before going out for a party. The spiked metabolism would help you burn better when you eat at the party.Enjoy the festival, stay mindful throughout and have a great time! Happy Diwali Folks!!By Harshita Dilawri, Nutritionist & Diabetic EducatorKnow Your Nutrients, Delhi

Title: Showers make Indore air cleaner by 70% this Diwali
Body:
Indore: Air pollution level in city registered a record decline of over 70 per cent on Diwali night this year thanks to the incessant rains that started from early morning and continued till afternoon. However, noise pollution level increased by nearly three per cent. District pollution control board monitored the ambient air quality at six locations including DIG Office, Mhow Naka, pologround, Vijay Nagar (automatic station), Vijay Nagar (manual station) and Kothari Market. 
The average ambient air quality (PM10) level during Diwali declined by 214 points compared to PM10 level on Diwali day back in 2015, said officials. If compared with last year's Diwali, there is a decline of 185 marks. In 2018, PM10 value was recorded to be 258 during Diwali, a decrease of over 70 per cent. On normal days, it is recorded to be less than 100 per cubic metre. Officials said that incessant rain on day of Diwali was an important factor contributing to the decline in particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5) levels. "There was around 7mm rainfall recorded on Diwali. It started raining since early morning which continued till afternoon leading to a significant decline in PM10 level," said district pollution control board senior scientist Dilip Waghela. Difference of average PM2.5 level recorded a week before Diwali and on Sunday night as per the guidelines also declined by 19 points. "The average value of PM2.5 which was recorded to be 70 on October 20, decreased to 51 during Diwali," he added. The average noise pollution level recorded on Diwali was 71.59 decibel. Last year, it was recorded at 69.67 decibel.

Title: Ravan Dahan goes hi-tech with water-proof effigies, HD fireworks
Body:
Bhopal: Dussehra is here. Soaked in the festive spirit, people are ready to witness Ravan effigies burn. And the ongoing rain can play no spoilsport this year. To ensure that the king of Lanka meets his fiery end and the spectacle remains grand, Ravan Dahan organising committees have taken the tech route this year: Water-proof Ravan effigies and digital fireworks. 
Welcome to Kolar Dussehra maidan. At 105 feet, the Ravan here is not just the tallest in Madhya Pradesh but the effigy is high-tech as well. "The tallest Ravan effigy will meet his end amid traditional as well as digital fireworks. The digital fireworks will be projected on a large high-definition (HD) screen. The aim is not just to put a check on air pollution but also ensure that the rain does not spoil the festive mood," said president of Kolar Hindu Utsav Samiti, Ravindra Yati. The organisers say that have spent more than Rs 20 lakh on the event. "We spared no expenses," said Yati.The Kolar Ravan is set to get a tough fight from the Bittan Market Ravan in terms of the event grandeur. The effigy at Dussehra ground here will be a good 57 feet tall. "Every year we reduce the height of the effigy by a foot to symbolize that 'evil' in the society is reducing. This year the Ravan is 57 feet tall," said Sanjay Vyas of Bittan Market Dussehra Samiti.The effigies at BHEL Dussehra ground too are water-proof. "Though it rained for an hour today, nothing happened to the effigies kept out there in the open. The Ravan effigy is 50 feet tall while Meghnad and Kumbhakaran are 45 and 40 feet tall respectively," said AGM BHEL Tapan Suhane. The effigies were given a coat of polythene to prevent damage from rain. The organizers said they have made all arrangements for safety. "A fire-brigade tanker and an ambulance will be stationed at the venue. We have also made an iron frame to fire rockets in a straight line," said Suhane.This year the size of the oldest Dussehra celebrations has been reduced due to the change in venue. The T T Nagar Dussehra ground is under construction. As the burning of the effigies will take place near Kasturba School, the organisers have reduced the height of the effigies. "The height of the Ravan effigy has been reduced by 10 feet to ensure safety," said Om Prakesh Khurana, joint secretary of the T T Nagar Dussehra Utsav Samiti.Effigies have also been installed at Chhola maidan and other grounds and localities of the city.

Title: School kids pledge to shun firecrackers
Body: PATNA: Many schoolchildren in the city have pledged not to burn crackers this Diwali in a bid to prevent air pollution. An intensive campaign in this regard has been launched by Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB), under which the school kids are being made aware of ill effects of harmful gases emitted from burning crackers.The school kids are taking pledge of not burning crackers during morning prayer sessions. Incidentally, the air quality in Patna worsens in the peak winter months between November and January.Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) chairman Ashok Kumar Ghosh said involvement of people, especially children, are of paramount importance in raising awareness on environment conservation. "Government policies cannot work unless people are aware of their own safety and welfare," Ghosh added.BSPCB conducted an oath-taking ceremony in Krishna Niketan School on Tuesday. Addressing an assembly of 3,200 students, they encouraged them not to use firecrackers during Diwali. A short play was also conducted in the school.Arun Kumar, a scientist at BSPCB, said the focus of pollution-free Diwali campaign was exclusively on students. "National Institute of Technology-Patna was the first educational institute to start pollution-free campaign," he said.

Title: How many vehicles can city take, NGT asks Centre again
Body:
New Delhi: National Green Tribunal has rapped the Union road transport ministry over its failure to submit a report on the number of vehicles permitted to ply on Delhi roads in proportion to their capacity.Terming it as a "criminal offence", a bench headed by NGT chairperson Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel granted the last opportunity to the secretary of the ministry to furnish the report in a month. "It is unclear why the report is still pending despite the tribunal's order, violation of which is a criminal offence and may require coercive action," the bench added.The tribunal noted that it had ordered the ministry to conduct the study in October last year, which was scheduled to be heard on April 29, 2019. However, without the report, the case was adjourned thrice, it noted. "The applicant must furnish a complete set of papers to the secretary and file an affidavit of service within a week," NGT said, while posting the matter to December 9.Noting the adverse impact of vehicular emissions on the air quality, the tribunal had directed the transport ministry to conduct a study on the number of vehicles that could be permitted in Delhi in proportion to the capacity of the roads.The green court had said the menace of illegal parking and encroachment was a serious issue not only in Delhi, but in all the major cities. 
The tribunal's directions had come while hearing a plea filed by a bus operator, Metro Transit Private Ltd, seeking direction to remove the hawkers, construction material lying on the roads and stop unauthorised parking. According to the applicant, it was difficult to conduct operations as substantial parts of the roads were occupied either by the hawkers or the vehicles, which lead to congestion, adding to the air pollution.

Title: Farmers get lessons on harmful effects of stubble burning
Body:
Bareilly: With air quality deteriorating from poor to severe in many parts of northern India, Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) at Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) here has taken up the task of training farmers on how to deal with stubble after harvesting. They are being primed about how stubble burning not only pollutes the air but also harms them -- causing loss of soil nutrients.Raj Karan Singh, senior scientist and head of KVK, told TOI, "Stubble has nutrient contents -- 10 quintals of stubble contains 5.50 kg of nitrogen, 2.30 kg phosphorous, 1.20 kg sulphur, 20-25 kg potassium and 400 kg of organic matter. If stubble is not burnt but is decomposed in farms, there is a 20% increase in yield. 
Decomposed stubble makes grain filling better. There is an increment in tillers and grains per ear head."On the other hand, stubble burning impacts environment causing pollution, he added.According to officials, the training programme of farmers from villages of Bareilly will continue till the first week of December. During the training, KVK teams will also be demonstrating the use of equipment for safe disposal of stubble. Among the equipment are happy seeder, shrub master, RMB plough and zero till drill. Besides, KVK teams are involving students to create awareness among farmers.Singh said, "Farmers earlier used to manually harvest crop (paddy) leaving behind three- to-four-inch-long stubble. However, for the past few years, most of the farmers using machines for harvesting, leaving behind 20- to-22-inch-long stubble. A few farmers burn stubble as it is a convenient method for them. However, we are suggesting alternative methods." Mahesh Chander, joint director, extension education, IVRI, said, "We should suggest more ways to farmers on alternate use of stubble so that they are not forced to burn it."

Title: Exemptions, rules, fines and more: All you need to know about Delhi's odd-even scheme
Body: NEW DELHI: In the backdrop of severe air pollution, the odd-even scheme in the national capital will kick in from 8 am on Monday (November 4), with only even-numbered non-transport vehicles allowed on Delhi roads on the first day of the exercise.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal appealed to people on Sunday to follow the rules for the sake of their children and the city. He has also asked the government machinery to ensure that no person faces inconvenience due to the restrictions.Hundreds of teams of Delhi Traffic Police and the transport and revenue departments have been deployed for a strict implementation of the scheme.Here's everything you need to know about the road rationing scheme:

Title: How pollution is disrupting lives in Gurgaon
Body:
Gurgaon: Our lifespans are shrinking every year, and there's evidence to back up that claim.In a recent study on the air quality life index by the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago, it was shown that Indians living in the plains face having seven years lopped off their life expectancy. In Gurgaon, often ranked the most polluted city in the nation, that statistic assumes more menacing proportions.For many in Gurgaon, life has been disrupted by a smog that lingers like an overlong nightmare. It's a state of affairs for which the authorities, twiddling their thumbs while citizens daily breathe in a cocktail of toxins, are wholly culpable. "Crores of people are affected by this and still everyone is silent - are we waiting for the Great NCR Smog?"
 asked Raveesh Shrivastava, who recently became a father.Poignantly, Raveesh can't set eyes on his little one because of the thick haze that hangs ominously, and seemingly perpetually, over his hometown, leaving him and everyone else deprived of the sun's life-giving warmth. "Unfortunately, I never thought I will have to leave him because of this pollution; both my wife and baby are vulnerable. When I am myself waking up sneezing and coughing, how can I get the mother and child back?"For a week, Aadish Pal, who lives in Sector 50, has been suffering from an eye infection. "I was told by the doctor that itching of eyes is a common symptom which people in the city have been complaining about. My wife is also suffering from cold because of infection from the air we inhale," he told TOI.Pooja Aggarwal, a Faridabad resident who commutes to Gurgaon for work, likened the 10-minute wait for her shuttle outside office to being trapped in a gas chamber. "Normally, the smog clears and pollution levels come down a week after Diwali. But, this time it's persisting as if to haunt us, and remind us how we have created this Frankenstein's monster," she said, describing a scene straight out of a 19th-century Gothic novel."As such, breathing is difficult... the situation is really scary these days," continued Aggarwal, echoing the fears of many in the Millennium City. And if you're a pedestrian, it's an even harder life. For, you risk being exposed to traffic fumes and the suffocating smog. "I don't know what to complain about - the inability to breathe or (inability) to see roads while crossing them," remarked Rupesh Singh, a Delhi resident who works in an IT firm in Gurgaon.So dire is the situation that many, especially the elderly, feel it would be better if they left Gurgaon for good, only because they have been denied their basic right of clean air. "This is the fourth consecutive year that we are witnessing polluted air, and, at the age of 70, it is difficult to process air which is not suitable to breathe. I am unable to take morning and evening walks," lamented Praveen Agarwal, a resident of Sector 46.This city, he adds despondently, is no longer liveable. "We have been advised by doctors not to step out of our homes as the bad air will complicate our health issues."Predictably, city hospitals have been logging more visits from people complaining of breathing problems. According to Dr Piyush Goel, senior pulmonologist at Columbia Asia, there has been a 30% increase in respiratory cases, with new cases coming in every day. "There has also been an increase in health conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (or, COPD)," he revealed.Dr Arunesh Kumar - senior pulmonologist, and head of department, Chest Institute and Respiratory Medicine, Paras Hospital, Gurgaon - pointed to a rise of 30% in respiratory disorders in the past week, and an increase of 20% in new cases in the last couple of days alone. "The air now contains highly toxic heavy metals such as lead, copper, zinc, manganese, sodium, potassium, etc. Such presence of metals in the air can trigger an asthma attack in a patient, causing severe headaches and respiratory problems," he explained.More troublingly, Dr Goel reveals, overexposure to pollution can result in lung cancer. And even the foetus in a mother's womb, he adds, is not safe from air heavy with pollutants. This is, by any standards, a health emergency, but you wouldn't know it from the response (or lack thereof) from those in power, a response that's as invisible as the particulate matter that penetrates our noses, eyes and mouths.Kids, too, can't escape the effects of bad air. "I don't go out at all and staying indoors is not fun," rues Brinda Aggarwal, a Class IX student. She's not unlike other Gurgaon schoolchildren, silently cursing the pollution for keeping them inside. Meanwhile, Brinda's brother Rohan is more concerned about his studies than his health.Whether working professionals or schoolgoing children, housewives or senior citizens, the majority of Gurugrammers is struggling to make it through each day without fretting over their physical wellbeing. "We are worried about our health as we do not see any improvement in the condition, for the air quality is still in severe category," bemoans Pal. But, unlike the Londoners of 1952, they can't see a way out of this gloom.

Title: Goel flouts rule in protest, AAP says unfortunate
Body:
New Delhi: On Day 1, the road-rationing scheme allowed only even-numbered private cars on Delhi's roads. However, Delhi BJP leader and Rajya Sabha MP Vijay Goel travelled in his odd-numbered car to protest against the "gimmick". "This scheme is just a gimmick. The AAP government itself says the pollution is due to stubble burning, then how does the scheme help?"
 Goel asked while starting from Chandni Chowk. He later stopped at the roundabout near Le Meridian Hotel in central Delhi and volunteered to get penalised.Calling Goel's move "unfortunate", AAP said BJP leaders were sending a message to people to not follow Delhi government's efforts to curb air pollution. Transport minister Kailash Gahlot also met Goel at his residence with a bouquet of flowers to request him "to co-operate with the people of Delhi in the coming days".The last digit of Goel's SUV was 7 and he had got anti-government and anti-scheme slogans pasted all over it. A former Delhi BJP chief, Goel was accompanied by the party's Delhi in-charge, Shyam Jaju, West Delhi MP Parvesh Saheb Singh Verma and others. Goel was the most vocal BJP leader against the scheme during its first and second editions too. "I am doing this as a symbolic protest against the Kejriwal government's failure to do anything in five years to curb pollution in Delhi. It is now staging a drama and an election stunt in view of the coming assembly polls," Goel said. Speaking to Gahlot in front of the media, Goel said if the AAP government was serious, it should have called a meeting of all seven Delhi MPs. He also questioned its timing. All Delhi MPs are from BJP. Gahlot said, If 50% cars do not ply, at least some amount of pollution will reduce." The government found an unlikely supporter in Delhi Congress' Ajay Maken. "Vijay Goel MP-A LawMaker! Is deliberately driving an odd-number car on an even-numbered day! I've been (the) most vocal critic of Kejriwal - But I will never contribute to air pollution as a way of protest!" Maken tweeted.

Title: Haryana to cancel firearm licences of farmers who burnt crop residue
Body:
CHANDIGARH: In a deterrent measure to stop farmers in Haryana from burning stubble, which has become one of the reasons for massive air pollution, the state government has initiated the process to cancel their arms' licences.A large number of notices have been issued by the deputy commissioners of paddy sowing belts in the state to the farmers who were found to be involved in burning crop residue. Maximum of such notices have been issued in Sirsa and Fatehabad, districts with high number of arms' licences. The notices have been issued by the DCs, who also act as district magistrates, on receiving recommendations from the superintendents of police (SPs) of the area.The notices are issued to farmers, who are booked under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of IPC for burning stubble despite ban by the administration. 
On verification, if the police finds if the farmer who burnt stubble has been issued arms' licence, a recommendation is made by the SP concerned to the DC for cancellation of that licence with the remarks that keeping of arms licence by such person is "not in public interest".On receiving SP's recommendations, the DC issues a notice under Section 17 (3) of the Arms Act, 1959, beginning the process for cancellation of the licence of farmer concerned. According to the data received from the state agriculture department, nearly 1,500 FIRs have been registered till date in Haryana for burning stubble.Talking to TOI, one of the DCs said the move will be of great help for the administration to pressurise farmers indulging in stubble burning. Getting an arms' licence is not only a difficult task, but is also considered a matter of prestige in the local society. "This would certainly act as deterrent, as people do not want to lose their arms' licences that they had procured for self-defence. Legally also, once FIR is registered against them for defiance of government order, a ground is made for cancellation of licence," DC had informed.When contacted, Keshni Anand Arora, chief secretary Haryana, said the decision to cancel licences have been taken by the DCs at their level to control the situation of stubble burning in the state.Several other serious efforts are also being made by the authorities to stop stubble burning. "It was perhaps because of the stringent steps taken by the authorities, Haryana is able to control the incidents of fires due to stubble burning, when compared with Punjab. Clear directions have been issued, empowering DCs to take all possible steps to curb this menace," Arora said.According to S Narayanan, member secretary, Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB), till date, nearly 6,296 cases of stubble fire have been reported in the state this season when compare with previous year's 8,750 cases. He also confirmed that number of incidents of fire in Punjab is higher.

Title: Is air pollution also making us depressed? Studies agree
Body:
Unless you have been living under the rock, you must be well aware of the thick envelope of toxic air that has engulfed Delhi-NCR. The residents are waking up to irritated eyes, sore throat and a sensation of choking. The air pollution levels have reached a disturbing three-year high, well into the "severe" range.The dangers of air pollution on human health From respiratory distress to heart, brain and even the health of the expectant mothers, these unusually high levels of particulates in the air are known to cause several acute and chronic medical conditions. 
However, in addition to an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases and respiratory symptoms, this dangerous cocktail of air pollutants can damage your mental health as well.The psychological impact of the choking airExposure to high levels of air pollution has been linked with affecting brain development in children and worsen the existing mental health conditions. Yes, the dreaded air pollution seems to damage much more than the visible physiological effects. According to a journal published in the Lippincott Portfolio by Wolters Kluwer, the mental health of the teenagers is more susceptible to the damage caused by airborne particles.The studyTo conduct the research, 144 teenagers were given a social stress test which included a five-minute speech and a math test. Shockingly, after studying the adolescents' heart rate and other bodily responses, it was found that teenagers with a higher autonomic response to stress, also had an increased level of PM 2.5 near their house. While the association between polluted air and greater stressors has not been explained in the study, it re-emphasises the fact that toxic air may also damage neurodevelopment and cognitive function.How air pollution is STRESSING us outIt does not matter which news channel you put on or newspaper you pick up to read, they are flooded with the impact of deadly levels of air pollution. Moreover, the doctors have strongly advised avoiding stepping outside unless absolutely needed. People have also been asked to stop working out outdoors and avoid strenuous exercises which may cause rapid breathing. Short winter days, grey skies and the presence of choking air everywhere are bound to stress anyone out and contribute to a persistent low mood.Can air pollution also plunge you into depressionA report published in the Ochsner Journal points to data from China published in 2018. According to that data, every 1 standard deviation rise in particulate matter over an average PM2.5 concentration increases the likelihood of having mental illness (including depression) by 6.67%. Hence, dirty air is not only suffocating your lungs, but it also impacts the way you think. There is clearly a desperate need to conduct in-depth researches to determine the extent of damage air pollution is doing to our mental health.The bottom lineFor now, instead of panicking over the stuffy air and AQI updates, it is more important to focus on what needs to be done. From carpooling, reducing the number of times you use your car, using public transport, planting more trees to completely avoiding burning trash, there is a lot that can be done on an individual level.

Title: HP CM suggests to make pollution treatment plant mandatory for new industries
Body:
SHIMLA: Chief minister Jai Ram Thakur said that it should be made mandatory for all upcoming industrial units to have pollution treatment plant. He said that state pollution control board should also ensure that all the existing common effluent treatment plants should function properly so that water released downstream does not gets polluted. He said that special thrust should be laid on checking pollution in industrial towns like Baddi, Barotiwala, Nalagarh, Parwanoo and Kala Amb.While presiding over the meeting of Himachal Pradesh State Environmental Protection and Pollution Control Board at Shimla on Wednesday, Jai Ram Thakur said that work on improvement in functioning of existing common effluent treatment plant at Baddi, with respect to, connecting the convergence pipes to treat 1.10 MLD waste water from industries falling in river Sirsa catchment must be completed, at the earliest.He said that state government is committed to maintain pristine and salubrious environment in the state and would ensure that existing and new industrial units coming up in the State fulfil all the norms related to pollution control.He said that a proposal for setting up common effluent treatment plant at Kala Amb area in Sirmaur district, would be prepared to provide much relief to the people of area. 
He said that in addition to this, there was a proposal for setting up of solid waste management facility at Kala Amb.Jai Ram Thakur said that apart from water and solid waste pollution, concerted steps should also be taken to curb air pollution. He said that usually it had been felt that kutcha roads in industrial areas with heavy vehicular movement cause air pollution. He said that regular cleaning must be done of road dust and sprinkling of water on kutcha road through tankers.He said that trees should be planted along side roads and pucca pavements must be constructed along the roads. He said that efforts should also be made for developing green belts, gardens and parks in open areas so that people could be benefitted.He also directed the concerned authorities for ensuring proper design and laying of sewerage lines besides ensuring their proper maintenance.

Title: Delhi-NCR air pollution: Task force suggests lifting ban on dirty-fuel factories
Body:
NEW DELHI: As air quality improved on Saturday, the CPCB-led Graded Response Action Plan task force recommended lifting the ban on industries operating on coal in Delhi-NCR."Industrial operations such as coal-based industries in Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida, Greater Noida, Sonepat and Bahadurgarh, and non-PNG industries in Delhi, which were earlier banned by EPCA, may commence subject to taking adequate control measures and compliance to prescribed environmental norms," the task force stated.Supreme Court had on November 4 banned construction and demolition activities in the region till further orders. "Hot mix plant, ready mix plants and stone crusher shall continue to remain closed," the task force stated on Saturday.As part of pre-emptive steps during the polluted Diwali period, SC-appointed EPCA on suggestions of the task force ordered ban on construction from 6pm to 6am from October 26-30. On October 31, the ban was extended four more hours from 6pm to 10am. 
On November 1, complete ban was announced before the apex court blanket ban.During the meeting on Saturday, officials noted how improvement in AQI was observed, which reached 'very poor' from 'severe' and 'severe plus' categories it was hovering around in the past few days.The state pollution control boards and other implementing agencies have, however, been asked to continue to remain on alert, ensure regular surveillance and take all necessary actions to curb air polluting activities.Earlier, on November 6, the Supreme Court gave Delhi government seven days to fix the 13 spots identified as the most polluted in the city.

Title: Vijay's 'Thalapathy 64' shooting delayed due to pollution in Delhi
Body: The second schedule of shooting for Vijay's upcoming film directed by Lokesh Kanagaraj is happening in Delhi. While a couple of shooting of still of the star actor was doing the rounds over the internet recently, looks like the shooting for the film tentatively called 'Thalapathy 64' has taken a hit. The buzz is that the shooting is getting delayed and the team isn't able to shoot swiftly as planned due the air pollution in the capital city. The pollution in Delhi and neighbouring areas has reached a critical stage. The second schedule in Delhi for 'Thalapathy 64' was expected to last for about 40 days. But with the pollution issue, it is unknown if the team would continue the shooting there. Vijay Sethupathi, who is also part of the project was expected to join the team during the final leg of the schedule. The film also features Malavika Mohanan as the female lead, while Antony Varghese, Shantanu Bhagyaraj, Sriman, Srinath and Sanjeev will be seen in important roles. The film is produced by Xavier Britto under the banner XB Film Creators. On the technical front, the film has music by Anirudh Ravichander, cinematography by Sathyan Sooryan, and editing by Philomin Raj.

Title: No more flush & forget, it's time for decentralised faecal sludge mgmt
Body:
Mumbai: While crores of toilets have been built across the country, the question is: After you flush, what happens? The invisible underground activity that has long been associated with shame, caste and untouchability is finally being addressed with some urgency and being translated into government reports and targets."The earlier thought was 'flush and forget' but now the government is trying to change that," says Arumugam Kalimuthu, programme director of the Water and Sanitation Hygiene Institute, a research and advocacy non-profit organisation. "Current sanitation services are not keeping up with the amount of faecal sludge generated in cities, and there are enormous health hazards." 
He refers to the need for a decentralised approach to the sanitation chain-emptying, conveying, treating and, possibly, recycling human waste-which is now being viewed as the best scalable model.Recognising the inadequacy of the sewer line network, the state government recently resolved to build 311 decentralised sewage treatment plants, starting with one in Nagpur. Some 74 plants are already operational in towns. Odisha also has fecal sludge treatment plants in seven cities and recently committed to scale up to 114 urban local bodies.The decentralised approach  is based on a local faecal sanitation chain, which separates liquid and solid waste and treats them separately (see graphic). While treated solid waste is used as compost in agriculture, the liquid waste meets water needs. When treated correctly, human waste can be converted into useful byproducts, including fuel, fertiliser and irrigation water. The model is based on a treatment plant set up in Devanahalli, Bengaluru, by Consortium for DEWATS (Decentralised Wastewater Treatment Systems) Dissemination Society in partnership with the local government. The Rs 60-lakh plant can service 35,000 to 40,000 people.Government figures reveal that only 37% of the total 62,000 million litres per day of sewage generated in urban India is treated. Based on lastest census data, 32.7% of urban households are connected to a piped sewer system, whereas 38.2% dispose of wastes into septic tanks and about 7% into pit latrines, underlining the pre-dominance of on-site arrangements. Many septic tanks built by private operators are not properly lined at the bottom, according to the Centre for Science and Environment. Also, even if the outlet from a septic tank is connected to a stormwater drain, it could be a public health hazard as the liquid run-off needs to be channeled into soak pits or other appropriate systems. According to Energy Alternatives India estimates, India produces 1.2 lakh tonnes of faecal sludge a day, and 60% of it is dumped in water bodies or land. This results in water contamination and public health crisis. Experts point out that, like air pollution, the hazards of disorganised toilet management are class-agnostic.
