Title: Chennai choked on toxic smoke on Diwali: Data
Body:
CHENNAI: Air pollution was severe in Chennai on Diwali, with Sowcarpet recording an AQI of 786, followed by Nungambakkam at 565, Valasaravakkam 545, Triplicane 503 and Thiruvotriyur 436. AQI in the 50-100 range is considered safe. Noise pollution too was high between 66 and 79.7 decibels. The normal is 65 decibels during daytime and 55 decibels at night.Cracker buffs celebrated Diwali with such vengeance this year, that Chennai overtook Delhi as the nation's most polluted city for two consecutive days. 
Chennai's air pollution was the highest in a decade.The air quality index of Chennai used to be in 50-100 range on a normal day when factories, thermal stations and vehicular pollution exist. On Monday, however, it shot up to maximum of 786 in Sowcarpet. At 345, Besant Nagar recorded the least. T Nagar recorded 372, while Triplicane at 503, Nungambakkam 565, Valasaravakkam 545 and Thiruvotriyur 436 also sizzled. Last year, the AQI on Diwali day ranged between 342 and 385. And noise pollution ranged between 66 and 79.7 decibels. Given the fact that 22 micrograms per metre cube of PM2.5 is equivalent to smoking one cigarette, a Chennaiite and pups have inhaled particulate matter equal to 31 cigarettes when PM2.5 was in 690-700 range. As per central pollution control board norms, AQI of 0-50 is considered good and 50-100 is satisfactory. Anything above 400 is severe. G Sundararajan of Poovulagin Nanbargal said the AQI which used to be in the range of 50-100 spiking beyond 700 on Diwali showed that crackers were one of the major polluters. "We request the state government to take a decision and implement a complete ban on crackers like the Delhi government," he said. It was not just the air pollution and noise pollution that were high. Even cracker waste went up by 70 tonnes compared to last year, as per Chennai corporation data, indicating that cracker indeed was the villain. At night, the TNPCB realtime monitoring stations showed PM levels of 950 ug/ m3 between 11pm and 12am in some locations which is disastrous for health. The TNPCB, however, claimed weather conditions also played a role. "This is due to large number of people bursting fi recrackers (mainly night crackers and sky shots) and high relative humidity and low wind speed. The climatic condition is not conducive for the effective dispersion of the smoke emanated from the bursting of crackers," the TNPCB statement read. The board had set up seven temporary monitoring stations for 15 days and monitored the pre-Diwali and post-Diwali levels of the air quality index

Title: Shamli directs farmers to send stubble to cow shelters
Body: SHAMLI: As stubble burning is a primary factor for heavy air pollution in the Delhi and NCR region, the Shamli district administration is using a strict approach to prevent it. Besides, provision of free 15,000 bottles of bio-decomposers, farmers are advised to donate the bio waste after paddy harvest to cow shelters. "We have set a target to receive 600 tons of stubble waste to be deposited at cow shelters in the district and various methods of residue management are being taught to farmers through seminars," said DM Shamli Jasjeet Kaur. The district administration has warned that if any incident of stubble farming is found, FIR will be filed against the farmer and village Pradhan. Farmer leader Kapil Khatian told TOI, "We are facing the problem of fodder as crops have been affected due to late rain, straw has also decreased due to low yield of wheat. Thus, farmers will also use the leftover stubble as fodder. The government should take care of Delhi-NCR garbage dumps, prevent them from fire."

Title: Air pollution worsening underlying diseases, it's a silent killer: Guleria
Body:
As Delhi breathes its toxic air, former AIIMS director Dr Randeep Guleria, who heads the department of pulmonary medicine and sleep disorders at the institute, tells Somrita Ghosh that pollution is a silent killer that is worsening underlying diseases. He rues the failure of government policies because of a flawed process of formulating them.How do you think the air pollution crisis in Delhi has impacted our lives? We are observing two things: one is the acute effect on the elderly and children - their hospital visits have gone up. I also know people who leave the city during this time for other parts of country, for instance southern India, because the air quality is better there. 
Data also shows that heart attacks go up during this time because of inflammation in the blood vessels caused by PM 2.5 and other ultrafine particulate matter.What long-term effects of this severe air pollution have you seen? Our studies have shown that on 70-80% of days - leaving that one year of Covid - the AQI has either been poor, very poor or severe. So, people living in the Indo-Gangetic plains are continuously breathing air which is of poor quality and that starts affecting their overall health. There are more chances of heart attacks and chronic respiratory problems. In children, it leads to retarded lung growth -- the lungs grow till age of 20, and if you are breathing bad air, then the lung capacity is not as much as it should be. Studies have shown that children growing up in Delhi have poor lung capacity compared to those growing up in southern India. There are studies which say that living in Delhi is a risk factor for heart diseases as much as for high cholesterol. Earlier, the focus was just on lungs and heart but now it has been proved that pollution particles go to the blood and travel to other parts of body; so strokes, dementia and other disorders are being reported.So, are we at a stage where we can directly link air pollution with mortality? Air pollution is a silent killer...other mortality factors can be examined but not pollution. Pollution causes worsening of underlying diseases. If you have a respiratory problem and are exposed to pollution, then respiratory issues worsen. It may also cause lung cancer and heart attack but the links have to be shown. Data is strong in terms of large studies but definite tests are not there. Lancet had said pollution was linked to death of 1.24 million people in 2017. What was interesting about that paper was that it showed that disability adjusted life years (DALY), especially in people with respiratory tract infection, stroke, heart disease and chronic respiratory problems, was affected even more by pollution than smoking. So, we need to develop strategies to deal with this. Otherwise, the burden of disease will continue to increase because of something which is preventable.A lot has been said about policies and measures to curb pollution over so many years but there has been no positive outcome. Why do you think these policies haven't succeeded? We need to develop a strategy for taking all stakeholders on board. We need a strategy for the targeted people -- What are their concerns? It could be socio-economic, regional or ethnic. Secondly, a sustainable solution should be worked out by looking at all sectors and understanding the issues the Indo-Gangetic plain has. It is a landlocked area and, therefore, whenever the air pollution is severe, the smog settles down at ground level. A lot is dependent on the weather in this region unlike in the coastal areas, and, therefore, we have to work aggressively on this. Also, a follow-up of the plans need to be done because if one plan is not working, we need to find alternatives.Do you think all the stakeholders were not considered earlier before making such policies? Policies have been made but somehow the implementation was not right, and we need to find out why. We are talking of crop burning for years and there have been so many solutions but farmers have not accepted them. So, what can we do? How can we incentivise it, so that the farmers get more profit from not burning the stubble? Then there is the whole issue of educating them.What do you think about the measures adopted by the Delhi government -- smog towers, water sprinklers, curbs on vehicle movement etc? We need to generate data to show that these measures are effective because some of them may not be effective. Whether a short-term or a long-term solution, there has to be an analysis to see if it is working, whether it is sustainable and economically viable. Only then should it be implemented. Or, one should move to other ideas.

Title: Jhansi: Premier agricultural research institute official booked for stubble burning on campus
Body:
JHANSI: Taking cognizance of the satellite images showing stubble burning inside the campus of Indian Grassland and Fodder Research Institute (IGFRI) - a national institute under the administrative control of Indian Council of Agricultural Research, the district administration has lodged a case against the farm in-charge of the institute on Saturday.According to details, it was observed through the satellite images that the farm residue was being burnt, which is otherwise banned in a large portion inside the campus of the prestigious research institute.Taking the matter seriously, the administration ordered officials to lodge a case against the responsible authority of the institute. Subsequently, an FIR was lodged at Sipri Bazar police station on the application of district agriculture officer KK Singh against the farm in-charge at IGFRI.Sipri Bazar station officer JP Pal said that a case has been lodged under different sections of IPC and Environment Protection Act 1986.Talking to TOI, IGFRI director Amresh Chandra regretted the act, saying that it was unknowingly done by the labourers. He, however, clarified that the residue which was burnt was not of crop, but of the fodder grown for the cattle.IGFRI is one of the premier research institutes under ICAR working on fodder crops for the farmers of Bundelkhand since 1962.Stubble burning has emerged as one of the major sources of air pollution in north India. 
According to estimates, about 23 million tonnes of paddy stubble are burnt annually by the farmers in northern India. Burning of stubble produces CO2, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, ash (black carbon) and SO2. In the recent years, it has become a major concern in Punjab, Haryana, Delhi-NCR and western Uttar Pradesh.Experts say stubble can be used in different ways like cattle feed, compost manure, roofing in rural areas, biomass energy, mushroom cultivation, packing materials, fuel, paper, bioethanol and industrial production.

Title: Steady winds keep NCR air quality clean, pollution levels to fall further
Body:
Noida: The air quality of Noida and Ghaziabad remained in the 'moderate' category for the second consecutive day on Tuesday with the air quality index (AQI) being recorded at 136 and 159, respectively. The AQI in Greater Noida was recorded at 192. The System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) said, "For the next three days, surface wind speed (8 to 16 km/h) and temperature (max 27-26 degrees C; min 8 degrees C) are likely to improve the AQI. The air quality is likely to remain within 'moderate' or 'lower end of poor' for the next three days due to moderate surface wind speed." 
A Noida Authority official said that they have been sprinkling water from STPs to mitigate the dust pollution. The Authority also tweeted photos of some tankers sprinkling water on roads in sectors 37, 38, 126, 135 and others. The minimum temperature recorded in Noida on Tuesday was 14.2 degrees Celsius and maximum was 26.1 degrees Celsius temperatures with fog in the morning. Ghaziabad recorded the minimum at 12.9 degrees Celsius and maximum 25.1 degrees Celsius temperatures. Meanwhile, Delhi's air quality improved remarkably and turned 'moderate' with a clean sky and cool north-westerly winds making it a soothing Tuesday.
The air quality index (AQI), on a scale of 0 to 500, was 177 as against 218 a day earlier and 306 on Sunday. This is the cleanest air the city has breathed since October 15 when the AQI was 186. This is also the cleanest December day in at least two years, as none of the days in December 2021 saw moderate air quality. On December 14, 2020, the AQI was 160.
According to pollution monitoring agencies, the air quality may improve further due to persistent winds and clear sky, which support ventilation of pollutants.
"The relatively stronger winds and better ventilation conditions are likely to prevail from December 13 to 15. The air quality is likely to improve further and remain in the moderate category on December 14. It may deteriorate marginally but remain in the same category on December 15. It will reach the poor category on December 16," stated the air quality early warning system.The maximum temperature hovered around 26 degrees Celsius, while the minimum temperature was recorded at 8.9 degrees Celsius.

Title: NGT directs 100% waste processing in Hamirpur
Body: SHIMLA: On the issue of violation of provisions of Air and Water Pollution Acts in Dughneri village of Hamirpur district in Himachal Pradesh, on account of the failure of authorities to handle the waste that is being burnt, causing air pollution, resulting in diseases, loss of livestock and contributing to forest fires and loss of wildlife, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the state to take further remedial measures expeditiously to accomplish 100% waste processing with zero legacy waste keeping in view the statutory timelines under the Solid Waste Management Rules, 2016. The NGT also said advancing the proposed timelines and compliance report of the status as on February 28, should be filed by March 15 and further directed the secretary (urban development) to oversee the remedial measures.Some local residents of Dughneri village had filed an application before the NGT against the violation of Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981 and Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974 in Dughneri and claimed that there is increase in population of monkeys, feral dogs and scavengers namely crows and vultures. They said the dump site in the hilly terrain is overflowing and contaminating the water body, which is a source of irrigation.

Title: CM Arvind Kejriwal's statements false, fabricated,twisted, says Delhi LG VK Saxena
Body:
NEW DELHI: In a stinging rebuttal to CM Arvind Kejriwal's statements at his press conference, LG V K Saxena has accused him of attributing to him "misleading, patently false and fabricated" statements."All statements attributed by the CM to the LG at his press conference after the meeting with regards to orders of the Supreme Court, powers as administrator, supremacy over all subjects and directions to officers are misleading, patently false and fabricated and twisted to suit a particular agenda. These statements are categorically denied," said the LG's office.  Work for development of city, LG tells CMIn a rebuttal to CM Arvind Kejriwal's press conference, LG V K Saxena's office said, "The CM will also be well advised to function in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, parliamentary acts and Supreme Court's judgments and refrain from running down an existing law just because it has been challenged in a court of law."Saxena said in a statement that he had taken up the issue of jurisdiction over certain subjects raised by the CM through various letters in the past few days and briefed him on his constitutional position and powers under various acts, statutes and court directions.The LG urged Kejriwal not to "politicise" every issue and asked him to work for the development of Delhi with "administrative effectiveness and fiscal prudence" in line with the Constitution.The AAP government, however, called the statement "malicious" and alleged that the LG's office had "cooked up" stories about things which were never discussed at the meeting. 
Raj Niwas said the LG reiterated at the meeting that he was "singularly bound by the Constitution" in discharge of his duties. "All his actions/decisions had been in conformity with the Constitution, acts of Parliament, statutes and judgments given by courts, from time to time," the statement read.Stressing that the well-being of people was the prime concern of both, the LG's office said Saxena deliberated with Kejriwal on various issues related to governance, administration and development of Delhi and flagged areas that needed attention. The statement added that "immoral" continuation of Satyendar Jain as a minister despite him being in prison for long was among the issues raised by the LG."Illegal appointment of private persons as government nominees on boards of private power distribution companies instead of government officers, despite written objections from two previous lieutenant governors, delay in projects of national and public importance, including redevelopment of AIIMS (and construction of) new academic blocks in IIT, expansion of Metro and NHAI works (and) corruption in government departments cropped up in the discussion," said the statement."Broken and potholed roads, air pollution and worsening condition of the Yamuna, no new hospital, school, college and flyover in the last eight years, encroachment of the river floodplains, worsened drainage system leading to severe waterlogging and no effort to clean the Najafgarh drain were other issues," it added.Raj Niwas added that the LG urged the CM to focus on the issues of the city and gave examples of the removal of over 40 lakh metric tonnes of garbage from three landfill sites and cleaning of more than 10km of the Najafgarh drain in just six months. "This was the result of the concerted efforts on part of various agencies, regular field visits and constant monitoring," the statement quoted the LG as telling Kejriwal at the meeting. The Delhi government, however, accused the LG of cooking up stories. "The LG's office has cooked up stories (on issues) that were never discussed at the meeting. It seems that the LG's office had already typed and prepared a dossier from its coloured lens before the meeting and was ready to share it with the media irrespective of what took place at the meeting," the government said in a statement."We strongly condemn such agenda-driven politics being played out in the name of a constitutional office. Raj Niwas must abstain from pointing guns at the elected government in such a manner. The LG has clearly been subverting the Constitution and the law of the land and it does not suit him to cook up stories to defend his obstructionist working," it added.

Title: Empower local bodies to resolve urban emissions: Experts in Delhi
Body:
NEW DELHI: Local institutions and bodies must be empowered to resolve issues related to air pollution and urban emissions, according to experts.A seminar on urban emissions, climate and health hazards held on Tuesday by Delhi Technological University's department of environmental engineering sought to bring together experts from various fields to discuss the causes and effects of urban emissions.
Track the pollution level in your cityThe discussion focused on exploring possible solutions to urban pollution by strengthening policies and the role of educational institutions in contributing towards better air quality. It also touched upon the importance of smart mobility and air quality forecasting systems.Speaking at the seminar, Rajeev Kumar Mishra, assistant professor, department of environmental engineering, DTU, stressed on the need to look for solutions "locally and readily available" in order to resolve the existing issues of urban pollution."For instance, to resolve dust pollution in my area, there should be a system wherein I can take MCD's aid quickly, rather than waiting for CPCB or DPCC for a solution. For this, we need to do capacity building for local institutions, such as MCD, and also enhance the capabilities of academic institutes like DTU, IITs and other universities and state-level colleges," said Mishra.Mishra added, "Governments must ensure their participation in resolving local air quality woes. Educational institutes must be engaged to sensitise residents in their cities and work in coordination with the municipalities to control urban emissions."DTU had earlier released research stating that the existing pollution under control (PUC) certification to control emissions from vehicles in Delhi is flawed.

Title: Mayor Sita Sahu: People's participation must to keep the Patna clean
Body: PATNA: Mayor Sita Sahu on Monday reviewed the sanitation work and awareness drive being carried out by the Indore-based private agency, to keep the city clean and green. She appreciated the steps being taken by the company for cleaning garbage vulnerable points in all 75 wards and hoped that with continuous effort, Patna will surely figure among the top 10 cities in the next Swachh Survekshan Survey.During the first empowered standing committee meeting organised at PMC headquarters, the mayor said people's participation was important in keeping the city clean. "Through the IEC programme, the civic body will organise several events and competitions for citizens' engagement and get their feedback," Sahu said. A demonstration was shown by a private player to combat the pollution in the city under clean climate action plan by adopting latest techniques. Sahu pointed out that the Patna's air quality has deteriorated more than Delhi and other metro cities, and it's time to take measures to curb the pollution. "A private agency, which has been working in Lucknow to eliminate the sources of air pollution, has also given its demonstration," the mayor said.

Title: Breathing ailments killed 13,500 in 5 years: BMC data
Body:
MUMBAI: Non-Covid respiratory ailments, including asthma, claimed 13,444 lives in Mumbai in the past five years, shows BMC data.The data assume significance at a time when the city is reeling under the unusual phenomenon of high air pollution levels in summer, and doctors' clinics are overrun with patients with allergies or throat infection and dry cough that persists for two to three weeks.'Air pollution indirect cause of death in respiratory ailments'BMC data shows over 1,000 deaths every year, roughly 1% of the total deaths in the city, occur due to asthma, a lung disease in which the airways get narrow and blocked by excess mucus. Even common chest infections such as acute bronchiolitis led to death in over 20 children every year. However, BMC executive health officer Dr Mangala Gomare said the data is not a reflection of the severity of air pollution. 
"This data is a compilation of death as per ICD (international classification of death) coding. Many doctors, especially those not attached to medical colleges and hospitals, are not often accurate in their ICD classification," she said.A senior civic hospital doctor said based on the present ICD data, it cannot be said air pollution leads to high mortality. However, a study released by the NGO Greenpeace-Southeast Asia in 2021 said Mumbai ranked fifth globally in annual deaths due to air pollution, with 25,000 deaths occurring in 2020. Delhi was the highest with 54,000 deaths related to air pollution the same year. Dr Salil Bendre, who heads the department of chest medicine at Nanavati Hospital, Juhu, said while air pollution worsens the symptoms of chronic pulmonary conditions such as asthma and COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), "it is the repeated infections that cause a problem". COPD is considered a preventable disease that worsens due to air pollution and causes 8.7% of the total deaths in India. "It is not an asthmatic attack or COPD exacerbation that suddenly kills a person, it's the effect of years of such attacks on lungs. The lungs get so weakened that the probability of death increases,'' he said. In other words, air pollution is an indirect cause of death in the person. Air pollution-related morbidity has been high this year so far. Internal medicine specialist Dr Shobha Subramanian Itolikar from Fortis Hospital, Mulund said she is seeing many young people, especially those who step out to work, coming in with acute respiratory illness. "After Covid, acute respiratory illness is leading to an overwhelming rise in the number of patients coming in with breathing difficulty,'' she said. Patients come in with complaints of severe breathlessness or unrelenting cough that disturbs their sleep. "Most of the cases are due to acute allergic bronchitis, viral bronchitis or viral pneumonia, and the plummeting air quality is worsening the problem," said Dr Subramanian Itolikar. Dr Bendra concurred, saying patients coming in with pollution-related problems are higher than those with flurelated respiratory problems. "However, at times, patients themselves contribute to the burden by not complying with treatment. Inhalers are the best treatment option for patients with asthma and COPD, but many refuse to continue with it when they start feeling better," he said.

Title: Failure to comply with norms: Pay 2cr, NHAI told
Body:
Chandigarh: Coming down heavily on the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) for failing to comply with environmental obligations while constructing of eight-lane highway No. 44 from Mukarba Chowk to Singhu border, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the highway authority to pay Rs 2 crore as compensation.
The tribunal has clarified that the NHAI would be free to recover the amount from erring officers/contractors following due process of law. "Air pollution control norms are an essential component of sustainable development. Any activity resulting in generation of dust has to be accompanied by dust control measures that have not been taken. Remedial action may be taken expeditiously and for the past violation, we require the NHAI to pay compensation of Rs. 2 crore to be deposited with the principal chief conservator of forests (PCCF), head of forestry force (HoFF), Haryana within one month. This will be in addition to levy of compensation by any other authority," observed the tribunal in its detailed orders.
The NGT has also clarified that the amount of Rs 2 crore shall be utilized for restoration measures in the area by suitable plantation in addition to the remedial measures to be taken by the NHAI by preparing an action plan with the approval of joint committee of CPCB and director (environment), Delhi, within one month. The approved plan may be executed within three months.
The copy of the order has been forwarded to the chief secretary, Haryana; chief secretary, Delhi; chairman, NHAI; PCCF (HoFF), Haryana; CPCB and director (environment), Delhi, for compliance. The NGT bench headed by its chairperson Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel has passed these orders while hearing an application filed by one Prem Prakash Prajapati.
Grievance in the application was against failure of the NHAI in complying with its environmental obligations in the course of construction of eight-lane highway No. 44 from Mukarba Chowk to Singhu border, Delhi. It was stated that near Khampur village a lot of dust is generated in absence of sprinkling of water. Other hotspots are Palla-Mod, Singhola Mod, Vaishnav Dhaba to Khampur village.

Title: 'Smog towers not effective at city level'
Body:
Mumbai: Some experts on Thursday said the BMC decision to set up smog towers could turn out to be a "white elephant". They were speaking at a webinar organised by city NGO Waatavaran.
Owing to Mumbai's worsening air quality the BMC in its budget last month announced 14 smog towers.
Dr Abhijeet Chatterjee, associate professor, Bose Institute, department of science and technology, said: "Smog towers as per the scientific evidence are only effective in cleaning the indoor air where the amount of air driven is minimal and released back in a small and closed space like a room. It is absurd to think that these systems could be effective on a city level."
Dr K V George, senior principal scientist and head, air pollution control division, NEERI, said: "Even if the towers operate at more than 100% efficiency, they will not be able to purify the ambient air due to its scale."

Title: Air quality turns 'poor' in Patna
Body:
PATNA: Despite the early onset of summer and rising temperature (above normal), air pollution in the city remained higher than usual during this time of the year. Patna's air quality index (AQI) jumped to the "poor" category on Thursday from "moderate" on Wednesday.The overall pollution level of the city has gone up by 33 notches and it was recorded at 212 on Thursday, as per the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) bulletin released at 4pm. On Wednesday, the AQI level was at 179. Experts said the main cause behind the summer pollution was rise in the concentration level of fine particles (PM2.5 and PM10), dust from the construction sites and the vehicular movement.Arun Kumar, a senior scientist and air pollution expert at Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB), said the dust-laden wind has been impacting the air quality of Patna despite the favourable meteorological conditions. 
"In recent past, it was seen that air pollution level rises during summer as the weather warms up and the wind velocity increases, due to which higher concentration of coarse particle is seen in the environment," he said.Kumar added that due to rise in temperature, the soil and silt deposited near the river becomes dry and easily spreads in the air with the wind. "The main reason is the alluvial soil, which is very light and found in abundance (almost 98% soil) in the state. Dust particles from construction sites and vehicular movement have also attributed in the rise in air pollution," Kumar said."The BSPCB has developed a portal to register complaint about open construction work, burning of biomass and garbage, open transportation of construction materials and other environment issues. The department concerned will find solutions to these problems and take the action accordingly," Kumar added.As far as vehicular dust is concerned, Kumar said steps are being taken to curb the pollution and smoke emission form the vehicles. "Diesel autos are already banned in the city while diesel-run buses will also go off the roads this year," he said.The average concentrations of PM 2.5 (particulate matter less than 2.5 micron) stood at 64 micrograms per cubic metre (g/m3) on Thursday, which is almost 4.3 times more than the permissible limit. If the level goes to 35, the air is considered unhealthy and can cause health issues to those suffering from breathing problem and asthma. The PM10 (particulate matter less than 10 microns) was recorded at 139 g/m3 on Thursday.An AQI between zero and 50 is considered "good", 51 and 100 "satisfactory", 101 and 200 "moderate", 201 and 300 "poor", 301 and 400 "very poor", and 401 and 500 "severe". According to the CPCB, the "poor" air can cause breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure.

Title: Rain gives pollution a break in Pune, Delhi, Mumbai
Body:
PUNE: Worsening pollution levels got a break this year, with Pune, Delhi, Mumbai and Ahmedabad witnessing a significant decline in pollutants PM 10 and PM 2.5 concentrations both in March and April 2023 as compared to the same period the previous year, SAFAR-IITM data showed, reports Neha Madaan.SAFAR-IITM experts said the air quality in some of the major cities in India has been the best during the season since 2021, largely due to frequent rain spells received in many parts of the country. Delhi witnessed a 32% decrease in PM 10 concentration in March this year (135.5 g/m) compared to the same period in 2022 (197.9 g/m).The national capital also saw a significant drop in this pollutant of nearly 33% in April this year (164.5 g/ m3 ) in comparison to last April (247 g/m3 ). PM 2.5 concentrations in Delhi reduced by 23% in March (62 g/m3 ) and 33% in April (57.7 g/m3 ) this year, in comparison to the same period last year (80 g/m3 in March 2022 and 85.8 g/m3 in April 2022). Pune, too, saw a reduction in the pollution levels, with PM 10 concentrations dropping by 14% this March (92 g/m3 ) compared to last March (107 g/m3 ), and falling by 20% in April (77 g/m3 ) compared to last year (96 g/m3 ). PM 2.5 levels also dropped in the city over the last two months, to 57 g/m3 in March and 44 g/m3 in April this year. 
Last year, these values were 65 g/m3 in March and 58 g/m3 in April. The trend was not limited to Delhi and Pune alone. Mumbai and Ahmedabad also saw similar drops in March and April this year. SAFAR-IITM experts attributed the reduction in pollution levels to the frequent rain spells received in many parts of India this season. Rain plays a significant role in washing away pollutants, which is why the monsoon season has the least polluted air in India. A SAFAR-IITM scientist said, "One of the main ways by which rain spells can reduce pollution is by 'washing away' pollutants from the air and depositing them on the ground. This process is known as wet deposition. It can help remove particulate matter and other pollutants from the atmosphere. Additionally, rain can help disperse pollutants by mixing them with air currents and diluting their concentration in the atmosphere."Another way that rain can help control pollution is by reducing the formation of secondary pollutants such as ozone. "When the atmosphere is dry, pollutants react with sunlight to form ozone, which can be harmful. When it rains, the moisture in the air helps reduce the amount of ozone that is formed," the scientist said. The SAFAR data, in this report, did not include ozone concentrations in these cities.

Title: 28 tonnes of silt removed from Trichy city roads
Body:
Trichy: The Trichy Corporation organised a synchronised cleanliness drive to remove dust and silt accumulated on roads in all five zones of the city. The exclusive drive focused on cleaning the silt from both arterial and residential roads saw around 28 tonnes of dust/silt removed from roads. The silt and dust resuspend into the atmosphere and affect the ambient air quality.
A study conducted by Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) and Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) on Trichy city's air quality index in 2021 found that dust and silt accumulated on roads account for 42% of air pollution in the city.
The chief contributor to air pollution was exhaust from vehicles (45%). Based on the directives from TNPCB, corporation procured automated road sweepers, mini-road cleaners and trucks with water sprinklers. Subsequently, a drive aimed at improving the air quality index (AQI) was planned on Wednesday by deploying workers and machinery. 
In zone V, 10.2 tonnes of silt were removed, the highest among the five zones. In zone I and zone II, 6.9 tonnes and 5.4 tonnes of silt were removed respectively. "Most of the silt was accumulated along with the centre medians. As we have laid new end-to-end roads without leaving space, we expect the silt accumulation to come down gradually," an official source said. 
The civic body has planned to continue the drive periodically.

Title: Rural, urban PM2.5 improves in Bengal: Study
Body:
KOLKATA: Fine particulate pollution (caused by PM2.5) has dipped sharply in Bengal- 14.9% in urban areas and 15.9% in rural areas - between 2017 and 2022, according to a study. The finding was consistent with a downward in PM2.5 levels across the country.
Track the pollution level in your cityThe study, conducted by Climate Trends, a private research-based consulting and capacity building initiative, analysed two sets of data: IIT-Delhi professor Sagnik Dey's SAANS (Satellite-Based Application For Air Quality Monitoring and Management at National Scale) data for PM2.5 estimation and Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) data for urban and rural classification.PM2.5 are fine particles, with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less, exposure to which can cause a host of health problems, from respiratory problems to cancer. The downward trend, noticed nationally, also reveals that the urban-rural divide in PM2.5 pollution has narrowed in the last few years. Across India, rural regions saw PM2.5 levels decline by 19.1% and urban regions recorded an 18.7% dip in PM 2.5 levels between 2017 and 2022, according to an analysis of the 1km x 1km satellite data available from IIT-Delhi. The analysis indicates that particulate pollution is a national concern, not just limited to specific regions."States in the Indo-Gangetic Plain - such as Uttar Pradesh, Delhi, Haryana and Bihar - have seen a significant dip in PM2.5 levels, indicating that the focus of the air pollution fight continues to remain in the region," said Aarti Khosla, Climate Trends director. "However, western states like Maharashtra and Gujarat have made little progress and have seen pollution become more significant."Despite year-on-year improvements in the Indo-Gangetic Plain states vs other states, the 2022 PM2.5 averages for both rural and urban areas in the country showed that levels remained above the Central Pollution Control Board's annual safe limit of 40 micrograms per cubic metre. The comparison between states that have National Clean Air Programme (NCAP) norms, versus those which don't, show a similar trend. This implies every Indian has had long-term exposure to air pollution.  The study highlighted the need to address air pollution on a broader scale, rather than focusing solely on urban areas."This analysis clearly indicates that India is inching towards plateauing its upward-rising air pollution levels since 2016-2017. This is a positive achievement. However, the challenge now lies towards bringing the needle down further, especially as we are in the last year of the National Clean Air Programme's (NCAP) targets of reducing 20%-30% particulate matter levels by 2024," said IIT professor Sagnik Dey, whose data for PM2.5 estimation was used for the study.With a reduction of 37.8% and 38.1% in urban and rural PM2.5 levels, Uttar Pradesh recorded the best progress between 2017 and 2022. Maharashtra was the worst performing state, with only a dip of 7.7% in urban PM2.5 levels, while with a decrease of 8.2% in rural PM2.5 levels, Gujarat made the least progress. Ten states witnessed an upward trajectory in urban and rural regions since the pandemic in 2020: Bihar, Goa, Gujarat, Kerala, Maharashtra, Telangana, Bengal, Andaman and Nicobar, Chandigarh and Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

Title: Emissions from power plants can form clouds: Study
Body:
Chennai: A study led by IIT Madras has found that sulphur dioxide in emissions from power plants converts into aerosols rich in sulphate that can form clouds. The study also found that sulphur dioxide emitted from the Neyveli power plant travelled all the way to Chennai and in the process generated secondary aerosols after undergoing a chemical reaction 
The study was conducted during the Covid-induced nationwide lockdown when emissions from vehicles and other industries were relatively low but power plants were functioning. Researchers said the study may provide key scientific insights for framing policies to curb PM2.5. 
 Prof Sachin S Gunthe, department of civil engineering, IITM, who led the international research team, said, "Our study provides a rare opportunity to examine the sensitivity of cloud-forming aerosol particles to new particle formation and growth due to SO2 emissions from a coal-fired power plant under relatively cleaner conditions. These findings have important implications for assessing the climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and highlight the need for comprehensive emission control measures." 
Researchers said during lockdown when emissions from vehicles and other industries stopped, the sulphur dioxide in the gas emissions from power plants interacted with the atmosphere and underwent oxidation before converting into small particles or aerosols very rich in sulphate, which have the potential to form clouds. 
On other days, when emissions from vehicles and other industries are also in the atmosphere, the gas condenses onto the pre-existing particles as they have a larger surface area. 
"Implementing aggressive measures to reduce particulate pollution originating from traffic and various industrial sources within coastal regions such as Chennai might lead to outcomes that work against the intended goals. As a result, there is a pressing need for comprehensive reconsideration and the exploration of alternative strategies to address air pollution at the regional level effectively," an IITM release said.

Title: To decongest Bengaluru, urban experts suggest 30-min model
Body:
BENGALURU: If food, medicine or grocery ordered online can reach our doorstep in 30 minutes, why does it take hours on end for citizens to commute to work, school and for recreation in Bengaluru? Why cannot city administrators ensure these commutes too are wrapped up within 30 minutes? These are questions that often crop up in the minds of Bengalureans who brave perennial traffic snarls on choked city streets.Seeking to emulate this swift service delivery model, prominent policy thinkers and urban planners have now suggested that the state government adopt the 30-minute city concept in Bengaluru to streamline the availability of citizen services, including transportation, commute to work or catching up with friends and family in the neighbourhood. 
Their suggestions are part of a recent comprehensive report - Karnataka's Decade - Roadmap to $1 Trillion Economy - prepared by the planning, programme monitoring and statistics department and Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) and released recently. The report seeks to draw a roadmap for Karnataka to emerge as a $1-trillion economy by 2033. Referring to the new concept, an urban thinker who was part of the roadmap planning, said: "Despite its economic ability, Bengaluru lags many Indian cities on several civic and infrastructural parameters. Rapid urbanisation and economic growth have resulted in haphazard development across Bengaluru, impacting the health of citizens and the environment. We call ourselves a global leader in innovation, but at the same time, quality of life in the city continues to be poor. This is where the globally fast-catching concept of 30-minute city can help in resolving this urban mess and ensuring availability of all crucial services needed for a citizen in a day around their neighbourhood."Stating that the 30-minute city concept is fast catching up with developing countries as part of their sustainable development strategies, the policymakers added, "The concept highlights the ability to meet most of our everyday needs locally, within minutes of stepping out of home by either by walking, cycling, riding or using public transport. Also, the concept helps strengthen the city's municipal governance model which wields very little power at this juncture, given the fact that all decisions are taken at the government level. It is pertinent to decentralise governance and empower the metropolitan wards by creating these facilities accessible within 30 minutes." Listing out the advantages of the 30-minute city concept, the report said, "Increased walkability and bikeability will lead to increased physical activity ensuring improved health. It reduces reliance on cars, curbing congestion and air pollution. Besides, it also improves spatial connectedness, encouraging social cohesion and community interaction. The concept also increases economic development by creating opportunities for small businesses and entrepreneurs to thrive." The report noted that neighbourhoods that are walkable, bikeable and replete with transit options contribute to empowerment of communities.

Title: Up for a joyride? Your safety, your problem
Body:
NEW DELHI: Before excitedly mounting a giant wheel in one of the many fairs dotting the city, it may be sobering to know that once up in the air, it's just you.A tragedy was averted on Wednesday after a giant wheel with people stopped mid-air at a fair in Narela, following which Delhi fire services rescued 20 people. A case was registered under IPC sections 287 (negligent conduct with respect to machinery) and 336 (act endangering the life or personal safety of others).At a Ramlila fair at Red Fort, a joyride called "cross wheel" malfunctioned too. A passenger cabin inside which children were sitting fell off, injuring a child. 
Days later, the ride was fixed by the foreman and was ready for operation. No case was registered after the accident."The cross ride is like a giant wheel but tilted. That day, the bolt came loose due to which the passenger cabin fell off. Luckily, the cabin was close to the ground when it got tilted and the child did not suffer major injuries. We have now fixed the ride and it is set to run," the operator of the ride said.A quick check at the big fairs in the city, including the fair at Ramlila Maidan, Red Fort and IP Extension, showed that at most places, safety norms are the last thing operators or revellers think about.According to the norms, to install joy rides at fairs or amusement parks, organisers have to take permission from Delhi police and MCD. "They (organisers of the fair) write to local police and MCD to check the safety measures. We seek a structure stability report. If the report is okay, we give permission," a senior police officer said.MCD officials said it has the responsibility to report on a joyride's working condition after an inspection. "The organisers have the responsibility to carry out the maintenance daily before operation," an official said. Additionally, there are a series of rules such as fitness certificates shall be issued to only Delhi-based Joy Ride Association Members or to firms based in Delhi. Also, owners should arrange for the display of safety measures, and entry/exit plan for each joyride. They should have adequate first aid arrangements. Owners must adhere to government rules for air and noise pollution. In most fairs the rules are flouted.When asked if any of the riders were informed about dos and don'ts while being on the ride or if they saw safety measures written somewhere, most people said they had not. Most operators did not have any first aid arrangements. Asked if foremen have to submit any report for maintenance of their joyride, most operators seemed unaware of such a thing.Shivam (25), who was getting down from a giant wheel, along with his friends, said: "We just buy a ticket and hop on without being told anything on what to do if the ride breaks or gets jammed. It's all a risk. If something happens midway, then it's a bad day for someone."

Title: A grid plan that can watch and check NCR pollution
Body:
NEW DELHI: Scientists at CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) are working on a grid-based mitigation strategy to watch and check air pollution across the National Capital Region (NCR).The entire NCR can be divided into small grids, akin to tiles, called Local Area Management Plan (LAMP). A network of stationary and mobile sensors can be used to monitor each area. 
Track the pollution level in your cityEach tile or LAMP - unique to that area - will be spread over an area of 2x2 square kilometres. Air pollution sources can be identified, their activity levels quantified along with daily pollutant emission loads. While NEERI has already done the exercise in Wazirpur, it is now working in the Siri Fort area and Bahadurgarh (Haryana).The approach is to treat air pollution at a local level, keeping in mind the diverse requirements of each area, instead of opting for a one-size-fits-all policy.A research article, titled Development of Strategic Air Quality Improvement Framework for Urban Hotspots, published by CSIR-NEERI in a reputed peer-reviewed journal, used a grid of tiles in the Wazirpur area pollution hotspot for summer and winter (summer from April to June 2019 and winter from December 2019 to January 2020).The study findings indicated that Wazirpur, an urban industrial area, saw high PM2.5 levels during winter followed by the summer season. The daily PM2.5 values were in the range 36-195 g/m3 during summer and 92-433 g/m3 in winter. The concentrations exceeded the daily standards of 60 g/m3, 80% of the time in summer and 100% of the time in winter, the study found.Out of the overall sources, road dust and industries were found to be the prominent emission sources emitting 53% and 28% as reflected in the PM2.5 concentrations. "Using developed framework (based on pollution reduction associated cost, social impact and ease of enforcement), the prioritized control actions for better air quality in the study area were identified- dust cleaning by mechanized vacuum machine, operation of industries with full capacity during day time only, installation of cyclone dust collector in industrial stacks, and increase in stack height by 50%," said the study."It is inferred that heterogeneous trends at the local level necessitates strategic and a smart criteria-based air quality management plan for designing any control intervention. The developed framework can aid regulatory agencies or urban local bodies in managing air quality at the local level," said the study, whose authors are Prachi Goyal, Sunil Gulia and SK Goyal.Speaking at the India Clean Air Summit (ICAS) 2023 in August, SK Goyal, the chief scientist and head (professor, AcSIR), CSIR-NEERI, Delhi Zonal Centre, said: "We will develop a grid-based mitigation strategy, termed 'Local Area Management Plan' (LAMP), for a hotspot, as a conceptual model for each season. The 'one size fits all' approach has rarely worked for air pollution mitigation. Hence, rather than similar actions across the city, LAMP will allow policymakers to have grid-wise mitigation and will make urban air pollution more manageable."

Title: Check stubble burning, LG tells Haryana, Punjab CMs
Body:
NEW DELHI: With the incidents of stubble burning in the neighbouring states on a rise, lieutenant governor VK Saxena wrote to the chief ministers of Haryana and Punjab on Saturday and urged them to take remedial measures to check the practice.In his letters, Saxena mentioned that the incidents of stubble burning recorded between September 15 and October 11 this year in both Haryana and Punjab were higher than the corresponding period in 2022 and urged them to "galvanise" all resources to defeat the deadly menace and help the residents of Delhi-NCR towns breathe easy.The city's air quality remained in the 'poor' category for the third consecutive day with the Air Quality Index of 257 on Saturday. In his letter to Punjab CM Bhagwant Mann, Saxena said it was "extremely worrisome" that the incidents of crop residue burning events in the border state between September 15 and October 11 this year reached 1063, which was 300 more than the figure in the corresponding period during 2022."Between October 24 and November 2, there had been an increase of 19 per cent in the incident of parali burning, in comparison to the corresponding period of the previous year. You would also recall that, last year, of the five states that affect Delhi's air quality, Punjab had remained the only non-performing outlier," the LG said in his letter, adding that both Mann and Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal had assured that the eventuality will not be repeated.TOI could not get a response from the Delhi government on this.In a separate communication to Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar, the LG said his state had done "exemplarily" last year by controlling stubble burning. 
"It is extremely worrisome that the incidents of crop residue burning events in Haryana during September 15 to October 11 this year have reached 340, which is 257 more than the figure of 83 in the corresponding period during 2022," Saxena said.Saxena further said he expected both the chief ministers to expedite remedial measures to prevent parali burning and save Delhi from choking in winters. "I am sure that you are seized of the matter and urge you to galvanise all available resources and make the farmers willing partners in defeating this deadly menace," he wrote to both Mann and Khattar.Saxena said being the national capital, Delhi housed the Parliament, Supreme Court and all diplomatic missions representing the globe, besides its two crore inhabitants. "It hosts lakhs of visitors, tourists and envoys coming to India for summits and conferences, who are exposed to debilitating air pollution, for no fault of theirs. This inter alia also has a bearing on the nation's international image and standing," the LG said.He added that Delhi was taking all steps to ensure that local causes of air pollution were fully addressed.Delhi BJP president Virendra Sachdeva said the residents of the capital were grateful to the LG for writing letters to the chief ministers of Haryana and Punjab to curb farm residual burning.

Title: Air pollution updates may be up again soon
Body:
NEW DELHI: With TOI flagging the missing air quality data for Delhi-NCR from the government-managed public platform, the Pune-based Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) on Friday said it would resume making those crucial figures on air pollution public after resolving the issue of multiplicity of existing forecasting systems in the next 2-3 days.IITM which works under the ministry of earth sciences (MoES) used to generate two sources of air-quality forecasts for Delhi-NCR - first was based on the System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) system while the second was based on Air Quality Early Warning System and Decision Support System.
Track the pollution level in your city "There were differences in the air-quality forecasts between the two forecasting systems, particularly with regard to the contribution of stubble (biomass) burning on the air-quality over Delhi. Additionally, it was noted that there were also differences in the grading of air quality categories between the two systems," said the IITM in a statement.Noting that the air-quality information generated from the two forecast systems was confusing for the general public, it said, "This matter was discussed among the scientists at IITM, India Meteorological Department (IMD) and MoES. Based on the discussions, it is agreed that a single source of air-quality information should be made available to the general public from the IITM website. "Presently, the scientists from IITM, IMD and MoES are working to resolve this issue in the next 2-3 days."SAFAR data on share of fire count (stubble burning) was discontinued on October 13 whereas the decision support system which used to estimate the contribution of local sources in the overall particulate matter (PM2.5) had stopped sharing the information publicly from Tuesday. This data is available to only officials who have login IDs.

Title: Post Diwali, air quality in city turns moderate
Body:
Lucknow: After witnessing high air pollution levels post Diwali, Lucknows air quality remained moderate for the second consecutive day on Thursday.
As per the data released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the Air Quality Index (AQI) of the city was 191.
On Monday and Tuesday, the city continued to be under the poor air quality category with AQI recording at 213 and 206 respectively due to bursting of crackers.
The drop in the pollution levels does not mean that things have improved. It is just the weather factor like high wind speed that has dispersed the pollutants. The moment the temperatures and wind velocity go down, the air quality will deteriorate again, said environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta.

Title: Mumbai air pollution: 350 BEST buses to get air-purifiers, traffic hotspots to get filtration chimneys
Body:
In an effort to combat rising air pollution in Mumbai, the city is implementing various technological counter-measures. The municipal authority is fitting vehicle-mounted air filters on 350 BEST buses, installing virtual chimneys at high traffic congestion spots, placing special streetlights, and implementing air purification systems in select gardens. These actions are part of a comprehensive strategy to address air quality issues, as per a PTI report.In a phased approach, 150 BEST buses will initially be fitted with detachable air filters to remove impurities from dust and particles. 
Subsequently, an additional 200 buses will undergo the same process. Minister Kesarkar suggested the introduction of new electric buses equipped with vehicle-mounted filters to expedite the installation of air filtration devices.In response to deteriorating air quality, the Maharashtra government has issued guidelines for air pollution mitigation, which the city civic body is now actively implementing. As part of the technological measures, ten virtual chimneys will be installed at high-traffic congestion locations to carry out extensive filtration. Additionally, "Vayu" streetlights will be installed at 50 locations to purify the air.Mumbai district guardian minister, Deepak Kesarkar, explained that the municipal body has taken several steps, including ordering 30 vehicles equipped with sprinklers, commonly known as fog cannons, to mitigate pollution. Notices have also been served to readymix concrete units, and industries have been directed to increase the height of their chimneys. To oversee the implementation of these technologies, both the Maharashtra Environment Department and the Mumbai civic chief are actively monitoring their progress.IIT Bombay is collaborating with various companies to test and assess new technologies for pollution reduction. Six technologies, including vehicle-mounted air filters, have been identified for trial implementation. The effectiveness of these technologies will determine their priority in the city's pollution control efforts.

Title: World Cup: Bangladesh cancel training due to poor air quality
Body: NEW DELHI: The Bangladesh team cancelled its training session at the Arun Jaitley Stadium here on Friday evening due to poor air quality prevailing in the Capital. Bangladesh are here for their match against Sri Lanka on November 6.Bangladesh had a practice session scheduled from 6 pm but they decided to call it off by afternoon seeing the excessive pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) around the Arun Jaitley Stadium had touched nearly 450 PM2 on Friday. "We had planned a training session but seeing the conditions we decided to cancel it. We still have another couple of days. The players were struggling outside yesterday (Thursday). They were coughing a lot. There is always a risk that one might fall sick," Bangladesh team director Khaled Mahmud said on Friday."If conditions improve on Saturday, well and good. Else, we may still have to turn up. We have to accept the conditions and move ahead. Our priority is to see that everyone stays fit," he added.

Title: Kanpurs AQI 201, morning walkers advised to mask up
Body:
Kanpur: Air quality index of Kanpur is an unhealthy 223. As per norms it is good if PM2.5 g/m3  averaged level is less than 12.5 over 24 hours, and if it is in the bracket of 12. 5-25, it is fair and it is poor if in the bracket of 25-50. More than 50-100 is very poor. Saturdays AQI level in the city was 201, which comes under the very poor category. 
AS per the WHO annual air quality guideline value, the city is facing 10.9 more PM 2.5 concentration which is the main source of air pollution. 
According to Dr S N Shukla, this quality of is unhealthy for sensitive persons and advised them to reduce outdoor activities and wear a mask when stepping out. Close windows to avoid dirty outdoor air and if possible get a monitor. Run an air purifier to make room air fresh, said the doctor.
He stated that since the morning temperature was dipping and air was laden with dew, morning walkers should take care of themselves and wear a mask.
Kanpur sees its air pollution problem mainlyfrom emission of vehicles and factories. The accumulation of dust and dirt rising within the city also plays a large role, along with human activities such as wood burning in homes, burning of garbage in the open, cooking.,excessive use of generators, very poor road conditions, and traffic congestion.

Title: Air pollution: Centre orders ban on non-essential construction work in Delhi-NCR
Body:
NEW DELHI: The pollution control panel at the Center on Thursday issued instructions to prohibit non-essential construction activities in Delhi-NCR and restrict the entry of diesel-consuming trucks into the capital, as the air quality in the city deteriorated to the 'severe' category.CHECK THE GRAP STAGES: 
Stage age I|| Stage II || Stage III || Stage IVThis measure is being implemented as part of Stage III of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), which is the central government's air pollution control strategy designed for execution in the region during the winter season.At 5 pm, the Air Quality Index (AQI) in Delhi was recorded at 402.During a meeting to assess the air quality situation in Delhi-NCR, the Commission for Air Quality Management (CAQM), a regulatory body tasked with formulating strategies to combat pollution in the region, reported that pollution levels are anticipated to rise further due to unfavorable meteorological and climatic conditions.The Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) classifies its actions into four stages based on the Air Quality Index (AQI) levels:Stage I - 'Poor' (AQI 201-300)Stage II - 'Very Poor' (AQI 301-400)Stage III - 'Severe' (AQI 401-450)Stage IV - 'Severe Plus' (AQI 450)These stages guide the implementation of appropriate measures to address air quality concerns in the region.In Stage III of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), there is a comprehensive suspension of construction and demolition activities, with exceptions made for essential government projects, mining, and stone crushing operations.This stringent measure is put in place to mitigate the adverse impact of air pollution and protect public health when air quality reaches the 'Severe' category (AQI 401-450). In Stage III of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), restrictions are imposed on the entry of certain vehicles to combat air pollution.This includes a ban on the entry of light commercial vehicles registered outside Delhi, as well as diesel-guzzling trucks, and medium and heavy goods vehicles, except those engaged in essential services. These measures are implemented to reduce vehicular emissions and improve air quality when the air quality index reaches the 'Severe' category (AQI 401-450).

Title: Pollution problem to climate crisis, IIT Open House tries to address all
Body:
NEW DELHI: From finding solutions to air pollution and disaster housing to climate crisis mitigation and detecting landslides, the 16th annual Open House at Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, had over 2,000 school students from more than 40 schools participating on Saturday. One of the standout projects, titled 'Sustainable and Affordable Homes using Agro-Residues: A Step Towards a Green Future', led by Kusum Saini, a PhD scholar, and Vasant Matsagar, professor of civil engineering, aims to turn agricultural solid waste into a valuable resource that addresses air pollution and the lack of housing, especially in remote areas. The building units for these sustainable and affordable homes are made from biocomposites of wheat and rice residues. 
The project, part of startup company BIOCOM Structures, is funded by the Industrial Research and Development at IIT-D. Saini explained, "These homes are easy to assemble and can be used in remote areas as permanent structures, healthcare facilities and disaster relief shelters. These biodegradable building units help address waste disposal challenges in high-altitude areas and reduce the carbon footprint associated with synthetic construction materials." During the event, Rangan Banerjee, IIT-D director, said, "The objective of Open House is to show school students what IIT-Delhi is doing in science and technology and showcase our work in areas that impact the real world. The idea is to encourage school students to make informed decisions about their future." Sunil Jha, chairman of Open House 2023, expressed satisfaction, saying, "Continuing the tradition of the last 15 years, Open House 2023 provided an insight into path-breaking research work, student projects and the numerous advanced facilities and laboratories available at IIT Delhi to the school students." The IIT Delhi Alumni Association recognised the outstanding projects at Open House and awarded prizes worth Rs 2.15 lakh to the researchers. One of the projects was an 'Easy-to-use Deep Learning based Landslide Detection Tool' developed by civil engineering students, including Ria Joshi and Harshul Malik, under the guidance of professor Manabendra Saharia and PhD guide Nirdesh Sharma. Given that the current landslide predictions require a large amount of annotated landslide remote sensing satellite data which is laborious and time-consuming to prepare, the new tool, according to Joshi, is "an open-source app available on Google Earth that speeds up all the landslide studies and landslide forecasting models, producing high-quality data within a minute with minimal human effort". Aaditeshwar Seth of the School of IT led the CoRE stack initiative. Seth said, "CoRE stack is a solution to provide rural communities with tools that can help them understand the socio-ecological aspects of their landscapes, make informed decisions, facilitate access to public and private funding and guide them on creating sustainable ecosystems."

Title: Delhi government announces odd-even curbs after Diwali
Body:
NEW DELHI: Delhi will again implement the odd-even traffic restriction plan  the fourth overall and the first since 2019  from November 13 to 20 as a measure to check air pollution after Diwali, the city government announced on Monday even as the capital continued to choke on severe air quality for the fifth straight day.While the government would share details of the plan in the next two-three days, officials said electric and CNG-run cars and two-wheelers are likely to remain exempted from the restrictions. The first meeting to work out the modalities in the presence of transport department officials and Delhi traffic police will likely take place on Tuesday.To safeguard the health of schoolchildren, the government also decided to suspend physical classes in all schools, except for students of classes X and XII preparing for board exams. A decision on making 50% of staff in government and private offices to work from home will be taken after Diwali.The odd-even rule restricts the number of private cars on roads based on their number plates. Vehicles with even last digit (including zero) are allowed to run on even dates and odd-numbered cars can ply on odd dates. 
These curbs have been imposed in the capital three times in the past after being introduced in 2016.The decision on implementing odd-even traffic curbs was taken in a meeting chaired by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday to discuss the alarming air quality in the capital.A 2018 joint study by The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI) and Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI) says vehicular emissions contribute 28% to Delhis PM2.5 levels and 24% to PM10 during winters.Addressing a press conference after the meeting, environment minister Rai said: The odd-even scheme will come into effect in Delhi after Diwali, running from November 13 to November 20.He added that the government will take a decision to extend the traffic restrictions beyond November 20 after assessing the situation at that time.In the previous editions, the government had exempted scooters and motorcycles, vehicles with CNG-stickers, women-only cars with children up to the age of 12 years and vehicles occupied by physically disabled persons.In December 2017, the odd-even rule had to be called off at the last moment after the National Green Tribunal refused to exempt two-wheelers from the scheme.Rai said that directives had been issued to implement stringent restrictions mandated under stage IV, the final of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) in Delhi-NCR to control air pollution.The restrictions under GRAP-IV, including a ban on all kinds of construction work and the entry of polluting trucks into the capital, kicked in on Sunday after air quality in the capital dropped to severe plus (AQI above 450) levels.The minister said that air pollution may improve over the next few days due to an expected increase in wind speed. He, however, cautioned that the air quality may deteriorate again due to factors such as firecracker burning during Diwali. Rai said directions had been issued to the police to keep their teams on alert, as Diwali was just a few days away. He also urged the BJP governments in Uttar Pradesh and Haryana to impose a ban on fireworks in their states to prevent the situation from deteriorating further.Rai added that the Delhi government had taken several long-term measures  introduction of electric buses, implementation of EV policy for private vehicles, increasing green cover and imposing ban on bursting crackers  to mitigate pollution, which had borne fruit.

Title: Reliance Industries joins hand with DBS Bank India to fuel green revolution with Compressed Biogas project
Body:
Reliance Industries and DBS Bank India have collaborated to introduce a financing initiative aimed at supporting the establishment of compressed biogas (CBG) plants. The initiative aims to foster the development of an ecosystem where vendor partners can aggregate agricultural residue as raw material for Reliance's CBG production plants throughout India.In a press release, the company highlighted the significant volume of agricultural residue in India, often disposed of through burning due to a lack of processing infrastructure and logistical support. The existing agricultural residue supply chain has been disorganized, with farmers and aggregators lacking proper incentives and financial support.Reliance Industries views this initiative as a crucial element in its net-zero roadmap. 
The company intends to invest nationwide to produce CBG as an eco-friendly alternative to imported compressed natural gas (CNG) and other fossil fuels, positioning India as a notable bio-fuel source. While CBG technology has advanced, commercialization necessitates new infrastructure and engagement with the value chain, involving farmers across various states, the company release said.Harindra K Tripathi, head of Bio-energy Business at Reliance Industries, emphasized the significance of CBG plants in utilizing organic waste, a major contributor to air pollution. "Beyond mitigating carbon emissions, the CBG plants will also contribute to the production of Fermented Organic Manure (FOM), enhancing soil fertility and reducing reliance on chemical fertilizers over time," Tripathi said.Rajat Verma, managing director and head of Institutional Banking at DBS Bank India, underscored the importance of India's green energy sector in the country's net-zero strategy. He commended Reliance Industries' bold initiative and emphasized the pivotal role of transition financing in enabling businesses to adopt and scale innovative technologies for decarbonization. Over the next five years, Reliance plans to establish approximately 100 CBG plants, consuming over 5.5 million tonnes per annum of agricultural residue and organic waste. This initiative is projected to result in a yearly reduction of nearly 2 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions.

Title: Bhopal air turns toxic again, AQI plunges to poor mark
Body:
Bhopal: Citys air quality deteriorated again as soon as the showers stopped.
Last week, showers did wonders; the air quality came down from very poor to satisfactory and moderate levels with AQI below 100 mark on November 27 and 28. The air pollution was constantly increasing over the past four days, and it doubled and crossed the 200 mark on Monday. 
During this time of year winds from Punjab and Delhi blow over the state due to which the air quality index of MP cities could go up to 20 per cent, said meteorological department officials of the Bhopal circle said. 
Secondly, the air pollutants come closer when the temperature falls. From the mid troposphere, it comes to the low troposphere, which increases pollution levels, the officials added. 
Experts point out that local factors like people burning tyres and plastic during cold nights, make the situation worse. 
The air pollution comes down during rains as dust gets heavy and does not fly in the air. 
Since Diwali, the air quality of Bhopal was not fit to breathe. However, showers last week brought it to satisfactory levels, but it went up again after the rain stopped in the city. 
Air quality is measured taking into account the levels of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxide (Nox), RSPM10 and fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air. Of the four, officials said, PM2.5 is the most harmful to health and causes severe lung diseases. 
PM 10 is due to dust, construction, including building of roads while PM2.5 is due to dust, human activity and climatic conditions.

Title: PM2.5 load uneven: Fewer good days in 2023 than last four years
Body:
GURGAON: The citys PM2.5 levels met the national ambient air quality standard (NAAQS) of 60 micrograms per cubic metre on just 115 days in 2023, according to Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA).PM2.5 levels were in the good category (up to 30 g/m3) on nine days in 2023. In contrast, 2022 reported 40 such days. In 2021, PM2.5 levels were good for 21 days; in 2020, for 49 days; and in 2019, for 31 days.According to CREA data, the citys PM2.5 levels met NAAQS norms on 109 days in 2022. The figure stood at 159 days in 2021, 173 days in 2020 and 122 days in 2019 (see graphic).The pollutant levels were satisfactory (30-60 g/m3) for 106 days in 2023, up from 69 days in 2022 but a dip from 2021 (138 days). There were seven severe pollution days (when PM2.5 levels were above 250 g/m3) last year  against just two in 2022 and five in 2021.The average PM2.5 concentration in 2023 was 90 g/m3, the same as the year before. Both were much higher than the NAAQS, which is 40 g/m3. The annual PM2.5 concentration was 92 g/m3 in 2021, 82 g/m3 in 2020 and 94 g/m3in 2019.PM2.5 refers to air particles that are 2.5 microns in diameter, which is approximately 1/30th the width of a strand of human hair. 
It consists of fine, toxic particles that can penetrate deep into the lungs, enter the bloodstream and cause heart disease, stroke and other respiratory diseases. PM2.5 data is a parameter widely used for assessing the impacts of air pollution on health.While there has been a notable decline in the frequency of poor air quality days in Gurgaon, the number of days with good air has decreased too. This suggests that while there has been some improvement in managing peak pollution episodes, the same persistent sources of pollution continue to compromise the citys air quality for a majority of the year, said Sunil Dahiya, an analyst at CREA.He added, Overall pollution levels have not seen a decrease since 2020. This implies a rise in the number of vehicles and heightened contributions from regional sources such as industries, power plants and construction activities, among others. The city requires a comprehensive action plan with targeted reductions in emission loads within the broader airshed.According to experts, the analysis reflects that the gradual long-term improvement in annual PM2.5 levels since 2018 came to a halt in the last two years. With a dip in stubble burning, an increase in rainfall between March to June, the annual pollutant levels should have improved. Instead, adverse meteorological conditions, specifically lower wind speeds, exacerbated the situation due to persistently high local pollution. The city had been experiencing a consistent decline in its annual PM2.5 levels since 2018. There was a drastic drop in 2020 due to lockdowns imposed during the pandemic. It increased slightly in 2021, but in the last two years, there has been no improvement, said Shubhansh Tiwari, a research associate at Centre for Science and Environment.As many as 11 Haryana cities are in the top 50 most polluted cities around the world, according to the 2021 World Air Quality Report. These include Hisar (with the average PM2.5 that year at 89 g/m3), Faridabad (88.9 g/m3), Rohtak (86.9 g/m3), Jind (84.1 g/m3), Gurgaon (92 g/m3), Dharuhera (75.8 g/m3), Charkhi Dadri (73.9 g/m3), Yamunanagar (73.3 g/m3), Sonipat (68.7 g/m3), Kurukshetra (68.1 g/m3) and Ambala (65.3 g/m3).
